Forum Post: 
Post title: Unable to pull written response (comments) from feedback using SQL
Post description: Hi, We currently have 10 questions in our feedback activity over 50 courses. The last question is a text box where students are asked any other aspects of the course you would like to comment on. I would like to bulk download I am an SQL beginner at best and have managed to get the following working... except for the last question of written comments. I thought the prefix_feedback_value was the prefix that managed this.. but im wrong? Can anyone help to edit this SQL so I can also download the comments and responses from all feedback activities please? SELECT c.fullname as "Course", f.name AS "Feedback", DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(fc.timemodified), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "When", IF(i.typ = 'label', i.presentation, i.name) AS "Question", CASE WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN SUBSTRING(i.presentation,7) END AS "Possible Answers", CASE i.typ WHEN 'multichoice' THEN v.value ELSE '-' END AS "Chosen Answer Num", CASE v.value WHEN 1 THEN SUBSTRING(i.presentation, 7, POSITION('|' IN i.presentation) - 7) ELSE CONCAT("More:", v.value) END AS "Chosen Answer Text" FROM prefix_feedback AS f JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id=f.course JOIN prefix_feedback_item AS i ON f.id=i.feedback JOIN prefix_feedback_completed AS fc ON f.id=fc.feedback LEFT JOIN prefix_feedback_value AS v ON v.completed=fc.id AND v.item=i.id WHERE i.typ IN ('label', 'multichoice') Look I know its not that pretty - but I am trying! ahahahah Thanks Sammi

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback - "Allow multiple submissions" selection tip is not understandable
Post description: Hello, Our teacher questioned the tip's text (the question mark) on Feedback, Settings, below "Question and submission settings" on the line "Allow multiple submissions". Text is now (Moodle 4.1.x - our: 4.1.14): "If enabled for anonymous surveys, users can submit feedback an unlimited number of times". Same is translated from this correctly same to Finnish. The question is: Should this be automatically allowed to answer multiple times when it is "Anonymous" - selection above? The tip gives the idea to that way. Should the tip's text be: "If this is enabled, answering multiple (or unlimited) times is allowed ". Simple as that. And also translations must be changed to similar. Reality in functionality is that this must be selected in any case to "Yes" when multiple answers is actually allowed when this is anonymous or not. If there is "No", all participants can answer only once (and quest access does not allow doing activities like write to this forum). Next point is the instructions to this: https://docs.moodle.org/405/en/Feedback_settings " Allow multiple submissions Choose here whether or not to allow users to complete the feeback more than once. This is important when using Feedback for anonymous surveys on the front page as it will allow non-logged in users to complete the feedback." Should this be even more clear and more understandable (and of course fix the writing error "feeback" to "feedback" on text)? This leads to think that Activity completion does not work if it is anonymous and allowed answering multiple times. Reality in our Moodle version is that is works in any case. Checked on the course with quest access allowed, feedback is not possible to use. No need to say "... non-logged ...". Maybe Google Translator translates this incorrect to mean "non logged people" like meaning "quest access" because guest cannot complete the feedback or start to answer it (at least what I know and have tested). Or does this mean that if the site front page (not course) is feedback as anonymous then ...  I don't quite understand. Teachers cannot set Feedback on site front page and I see this instructions page targeted more to teachers and less to site admins like me. And if I (or anyone our site admin team) cannot understand the tip or instructions page's message, how many teachers could understand it better (well, someone can but the point to most less technical people)? B.R. Petri Hörkkö

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 4.1 feedback activity not displaying teacher tabs -- Never Mind!
Post description: I created two feedback activities  last fall using (Moodle 3.9.1 and was able to edit prior templates and update questions. The first survey ran in October 2022 and I could list participants and review the results.  In December, I upgraded to Moodle  4.1 (20221222) and subsequently migrated the entire site to a new PHP 8.1 server in February.  The second survey opened in May 2023. Everything else in the Moodle seems to be working well....but today I discovered this May feedback activity is acting oddly. I am listed (manual enrollment) as the teacher for the course when reviewing the course listing as Moodle administrator. But when I go to the course after logging in as my teacher username, I am offered tabs to edit or preview the activity questions but there is no analysis tab or list of participants who have / have not completed the survey. When reviewing feedback activities for prior years in courses where I am the teacher, I can also no longer see the results. The only administrative feedback module setting involves allowing completely anonymous feedback; this is set to no, since all Moodle users must log in to get to the feedback activities. I have the sense that I missed a setting somewhere, but I can't figure out where. Moodle: 4.1 (20221222) OS: Linux VPS running PHP 8.1 and Mariadb 10.4.19 ACTUALLY, I did figure this out eventually.  The tabs are gone from the edit page, and now are options in the feedback activity block.  I'm not sure whether there's 4.0+ documentation pointing out this shift in display thinking, but if there is, I missed it. If you read this far, thank you for your time.  Now back to our regularly scheduled chaos...

Post title: Role change in Moodle 4.0 prevents front page feedback activities
Post description: I was struggling to get the feedback activity to work for students on the front page (in order to use the feedback block in courses). After a lot of digging I found that in 4.0 the "Authenticated User of Frontpage" role no longer has an permissions for the Feedback activity. Prior to 4.0 it had View and Complete permissions. Since this change, a feedback activity put on the frontpage will not be available for students to complete. It can be resolved by adding these permissions back in, but I'm curious as to whether the change was intentional since it breaks this particular functionality?

Post title: Remove preview questions button and link in Feedback Activity Moodle 4.0
Post description: Hi, I have recently upgraded to Moodle 4.0.1 and the "Preview questions" button in Feedback is much more obvious than in the previous versions, causing confusion for students and also allowing them to see all questions when a conditional set of questions is included, which they would not normally see. Can I hide the preview questions button and the link to print.php? I managed to hide it in our previous version (3.9) by commenting out the following code in feedback\view.php, but it has not worked in the new version $previewimg = $OUTPUT->pix_icon('t/preview', get_string('preview')); $previewlnk = new moodle_url('/mod/feedback/print.php', array('id' => $id)); if ($courseid) { $previewlnk->param('courseid', $courseid); } $preview = html_writer::link($previewlnk, $previewimg); I can see that this is showing as an unresolved issue in https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-63015 and https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70586 Does anyone have a workaround? Regards, Bronwen

Post title: Making resources hidden/orphaned but still accessible?
Post description: Moodle 3.11.4   I am struggling with making an
activity ' hidden but still
accessible ' in an orphaned section. In my previous Moodle version, I
housed my feedback question information in a section that was orphaned so
that - in an earlier, available course section - the feedback link took the
student directly to the page after 'answer the questions'. In the 3.11 Moodle
version, if I use the topics course format, that doesn't give me the ability to
subtract sections and make them available to students, but orphaned. If I use
collapsed topics, it gives me more control over adding and subtracting sections
but it also adds additional labels that aren't needed for me. If I hide the
section or topic, the student sees, 'sorry this activity is currently
hidden'. I was trying to send
the student directly to the feedback activity, without requiring him/her to
click on the 'answer the questions' button. In my previous Moodle version, the
feedback activity lived in the orphaned section, and the student was only
provided with a link to the page following 'answer the questions'. So it seems that my problem is the inability to add a section,
put accessible content in the section and next subtract the section, so
the student never sees it. This version doesn’t offer a + - section option at
the end of the page. I only used this for the feedback activity. If orphaned sections are no longer available, is there another way to offer the student a link directly to the feedback activity page?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Suggest a "Grade" for the submission of feedback
Post description: I am a big fan of the Moodle Feedback activity and have used it in a number of small research projects centred around my e-courses - see https://www.uib.no/en/radioweb/nuclear/specialist for references. I use Feedback in anonymous mode. One of the strengths of Feedback over competing modules is the template functionality. I currently run a big new e-course over 30 course weeks. The template functionality allows me to monitor each week with minimal labour for setting up the questions. Excellent! However, my course has a challenge. Each course week contains 3 - 4 quizes that need to be passed with at least 80 %. Then the week is passed in a binary fashion - either passed or not passed. Students have to pass all 30 days. I had trouble implementing this simple algorithm in standard Moodle and implemented a custom SQL query with the "Configurable Reports" plugin. However, there could be a much simpler way of settings things up if the "Feedback" activity had a grade. I would restrict access to the week's Feedback activity until all Query modules are passed with >= 80 %, then everyone who submitted feedback would get 100 % for the feedback activity. The course total would then be the sum of all feedback activities in the course. Kind regards Martin

Post title: How do I set up a new feedback/ course evaluation for all courses? And is there a way to set a timeline for instructors to access the results?
Post description: Hello, Our Moodle system had previously had mandatory course evaluations (feedback) the would automatically appear in each course shell that was created. There were the same general questions for all students to answers. Our instructors were required to turn on the course evaluation during the final week of classes, and then they were not able to view the results until two weeks after the course had closed, and even at that time, the results were anonymous. These were the settings that I inherited in my role and they were fully functional until about 3 months ago. Now instructors are not able to view the results at all, unless I give them manager rights. I have gone into the system admin section under users->permissions-> define roles and made sure that the instructor has access to the results, however this has not changed, and instructors still do not have access. I am curious if anyone else has run into this issue and could assist in a resolution? Or if anyone is new to setting up a similar scenario and might have some tips for me in the event that I have to recreate the entire feedback evaluation? Thank you in advance, I appreciate any assistance that can be offered!

Post title: How do I uninstall all instances of the Feedback activity plugin?
Post description: Moodle 3.7.2 We use the Feedback activity in each Moodle course page (3500+) to allow participants to return feedback to a standard set of questions about their course. We add them in by uploading a csv set to restore from a Feedback Template page that only contains the Feedback activity but we need to remove the old instances from every page first before uploading fresh ones for the current year. Is there a way to remove all instances of this plugin in one go? Or is there a way to uninstall it then re-install it afresh? There is no 'Uninstall' option for it within the 'Manage Activities' page and just removing the Feedback folder from the Mods folder causes a site error, presumably because this is a core plugin. I have tried truncating the various mdl_feedback_xxxx tables associated with the plugin but as soon as I start importing fresh instances it repopulates the course pages with the old instances as well, resulting in multiple instances of the Feedback on each page. Is this related to the references in the 'mdl_course_modules' table ('module' column)? Hoping someone can point me in the right direction with this. Many thanks Dominique

Post description: I have, several years ago, used a Feedback on the front page to gather responses from parents.  However, to prevent open access, parents were provided with a password.  The first question asks for this password.  The next page contains a required question conditional on the correct password being given in response to the first question. I want to run a further feedback but have found that this little trick does not work now as it seems that required questions only prevent movement to the next page if they are not completed when visible.  If the required question is invisible, the user can just pass to the next page without providing an answer, and continue with the questionnaire. I can't make all the questions conditional on the answer to the first as some of the late questions have their own conditional requirements.  Can anyone think of how I might be able to make this work?  I'm running Moodle 3.5.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback Tool for course evaluation surveys: questions
Post description: Hi I've been comparing feedback tool and questionnaire tool for Module Evaluation surveys. Feedback Tool displays much better on a mobile phone so thats my preference between the two. In terms of pushing a survey into course spaces I've seen the "map course" functionality, is that still current? https://docs.moodle.org/34/en/Capabilities/mod/feedback:mapcourse Can Feedback Tool ask a branching logic question: i.e "if they answered "b" then also ask an extra question"? I am assuming not but if there is a way it would be good to know. Can a question be locked, as part of a template, so that course owners can add more questions but not delete core questions? I am assuming not, but again, if there is a way it would be good to know. Questionnaire Tool provides a printable version: could there also be a printable version of the Feedback Tool? (for accessibility purposes, or for spares if students don't have devices with them). (and obviously a printed version isn't compatible with branching logic). This is a whole bigger ask, but could there be a way of aggregating reports so that category managers / people with higher level permissions could download multiple reports / multiple results as combined CSVs? If Moodle could do a little more on the data handling side it would be powerful. Plug-in/integration suggestions welcome (cheap!). Grateful for tips/suggestions on any of the above. Amber

Post title: How to respond to student feedback?
Post description: Hi there! First of all, I'm not a hundred percent sure if I use the Feedback module as intended of if i alienate it, but I want to use it like an anonymous letterbox. Students should be able voice criticism or problems that they don't want or aren't ready to talk to by person. The first part of this idea is pretty obvious and easy: I already created a Feedback activity with record user names set to anonymous and a couple of form elements. However, there's a big problem: I don't see a way to respond to their submissions. Which would be fine in many cases fine, but I cannot help someone if they tell me something important and I have no way to reach them. Did I overlook something or are there other ways? A plugin may do the job, but I'd like to do it without annoying the admin :D Kind regards!

Post title: Behavior changed; non-anonymous now overwrites previous
Post description: I was using the Feedback activity last year with Moodle 3.2 in a speech class. I set it up so students could submit multiple feedbacks (non-anonymous), and I was using it so that they could evaluate the other students' speeches. This worked flawlessly. I got all the submissions, downloaded them to Excel, and could go through them. I could then give students points for the evaluations. This year I've upgraded to Moodle 3.3 and used the same Feedback activity: multiple submissions and non-anonymous. Now it seems that each submission overwrites the previous submission. Why was this changed? And more importantly: What can I do now that this no longer works? It doesn't appear that there is any other activity that makes this type of activity possible.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Hiding feedback preview icon
Post description: I had an issue similar to that described in other discussions but from some reason was not able to leave a reply: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=251783 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=326327 Issue: students click the 'preview' icon, next to the Feedback form header, which takes them to a screen which allows them to fill the form, but not to save/submit it. Solution: A custom css (in this case within Essential theme) to hide the preview icon. The preview link is still there, but it icon is not visible. i.icon.fa.fa-search-plus.fa-fw { visibility: hidden; }

Post description: Hello, after upgrading to Moodle 3.1.1 the behaviour of the feedback activity seems to have changed: Settings: - Record user names: User's name will be logged and shown answers - Allow multiple submissions: yes We use this szenario for students to book certain courses via multiple choice elements. Now in M 3.1.1 when users submit a feedack and repopen the activity they do not see their initial selection and if they submit the form a second time a second response will be created. Can anybody confirm? Is that a bug or is it an intended feature? Thanks and regards Tobias Moodle 3.1.1 (Build: 20160711)

Post title: Other User Roll
Post description: Hello all. I am in need of some assistance with the Other User (s) in courses. At
our company there there are many departments with many managers that
are allowed to create and assign courses. We are a world wide company
and with that there are over 100+ user s with rolls like Department Manager, Site Manager, Course Creator, and so on. In
my department I have created a Feedback form using the Feedback module.
When one of the employees of my department fills out the Feedback form
(used for evaluation and progress in their job), it emails me, the
instructor of that department. However it also emails ALL of the 100+ Other User s that do not need or want this sent to them. Question: How can I limit these Other User s from a course and be able to control who gets the email notification? Any help is greatly appreciated and welcome. Thanks for your time, Dennis

Forum Post: 
Post title: Export answers to Feed-back activity into an Excel in a sensible way
Post description: Hello, Though the Feed-back activity allows to export the answers to an Excel spreadsheet, the way it is exported makes it difficult to analyze it. Example: imagine this very simple feed-back to measure degree of satisfaction at the end of a certain course: 1. Question 1: who has been your teacher? The user has to choose between two possibilities: John, Theresa 2. Question 2: How was he/she? The user has to choose between two possibilities: Good Bad. Because of the way the Excel is exported, we will know how many students had John and how many had Theresa. We will also know how many students think their teacher is good and how many think he/she is bad. But we won't know how many students think John is a good teacher. This would be solved if the export to Excel just follows basic table structure like this ANSWERS Question 1 Question 2 student 1 John Good student 2 John Bad student 3 Theresa Good This Excel could just be downloadable from the "Show responses" tab. This is just a suggestion. Our teachers usually miss this. Thanks, Gabriel

Forum Post: 
Post title: Including Submission Results in Email
Post description: As most people know, the feedback module is one of the few modules that guests can access.  As a result, it can be used for many purposes, such as a quick survey, contact form, etc.  One feature that is a bit difficult is the fact that the results are randomized and the email notifications do not include the submission values.  This makes it difficult for using it as a contact form.  For example, if a guest fills out the form and submits it, the admin gets an email saying the form was completed.  The link in the email sends the admin to the list of submissions, but since the submissions are randomized, it makes it nearly impossible to determine which one was just sent. Before Moodle 2, the Questionnaire module was handy for this because it sent all the form data in the email.  However, this cannot be used anymore with guests.  Joseph's suggestion is to use LimeSurvey, but I find it to be a bit cumbersome and also I don't want many to many systems for my sites. As a result, I created a patch for the Feedback module that will send the results of the feedback in the email.  Only two files were edited: lib.php (patch attached) complete_guest.php (only one line edited - shown below) Edit for complete_guest.php: Line 256, Moodle 2.7.1, replace 
```text
                feedback_send_email_anonym($cm, $feedback, $course, $userid);  //Original
```
 With 
```text
                feedback_send_email_anonym($cm, $feedback, $course, $new_completed_id);  //Edit
```
 It works well for us, however, I would appreciate any feedback as well as some help with fine tuning it. With the patch, every feedback submitted sends email to the "teacher" of the courses.  I would like to add one additional setting in the initial settings of the feedback so the person setting it up can decide whether to have the submissions sent to the teacher in an email or keep the original functionality. Maybe something like Include submission values in email (default no) Once this is in, I can make the appropriate changes in the two files to honor the setting. Any "feedback" would be appreciated (no pun intended... well, maybe some pun was intended) Thanks!

Post title: Guest access and Feedback functionality very misleading for Teachers
Post description: Using 2.4.3+ Guest access and Feedback functionality is very misleading for Teachers. The documentation is clear in that Guests can only use Feedback successfully on the front page of the Moodle yet, when Guests log in and access a Feedback within a course, by default, Moodle allows the Guest to click on the preview icon, fill out the form and click Continue.   The Guest doesn't necessarily know this is only a preview and that the results will not be saved.  There is no error or warning message and it appears to let the Guest complete the Feedback which is misleading to the Guest and the Teacher administering the site. I have found a way to get around this by modifying the Guest role so they are not able to view Feedbacks but my question is why would a guest even be allowed to access/preview a Feedback in a course if the functionality is disabled here?  What purpose does this serve if they cannot save results?  If there is a use-case for this, It might be useful to implement a warning at the very least so that guests are aware they are only previewing the Feedback and not actually completing the feedback.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 1.9 Feedback calculation of averages
Post description: We’ve been using the Feedback module for some time. Up to now, the Feedbacks are set for single submission, using: · ‘Required’  ‘Multiple choice (rated) single answer allowed (dropdown list); and · Optional ‘Longer text answers’. This setup works entirely reliably and the exported Excel workbook provides calculated averages for the numerically rated questions – which is what we need. The calculation of averages is based on the ‘requirement’ for each respondent to give a numerically rated value before the Feedback will be accepted when ‘Submit’ is selected. If a ‘required’ answer has been omitted, the individual’s responses are no accepted, and the user is prompted to supply a numerically-rated answer. For every numerically-rated answer, the average is calculated as the sum of each numerical value x the frequency of that value/the total number of people submitting responses to the Feedback. I’ve just introduced a different style of Feedback set to allow ‘Multiple submit’. This means that students can complete one Feedback progressively through an 8-week residential course. When they select ‘Submit’, their answers are recorded and saved. They can then re-enter the Feedback to add new responses and, if they wish, amend earlier responses in the light of course developments. Again, the Feedback employs a mixture of ‘Multiple choice (rated) single answer allowed (dropdown list); and ‘Longer text answers’. · However, it is not practical to set the Multiple choice (rated) questions to ‘Required’. · If that were done, then in, say, week one, all the students would have to give ratings for every week covered by the Feedback in order to ‘Submit’, even though the course had not yet dealt with the topics to which the questions related. Unfortunately, the Feedback calculation of averages does not cope with unreliable human beings! For each numerically-rated question, the average is the sum of each numerical value x the frequency of that value/the total number of people submitting responses to the Feedback. The algorithm does not take account of the number of people answering the question . The two are not necessarily then same, and therefore the automatically-calculated averages are not correct. Our need for this new style of using the Feedback module will increase in importance. So… Is it possible to modify the Feedback module to calculate averages based on the number of respondents to each question, rather than the maximum number of respondents to the Feedback as a whole?

Forum Post: Post title: Feedback - hide null answers in text fields/areas Post description: This is a minor change that one of my curriculum developers requested. We are using moodle 1.9 When viewing the analysis of feedback containing text based answers she wanted to not show the responces where the user did not provide an answer. I accomplished this by adding an if statement to the textfield lib.php and the text area lib.php files.  The respective files can be found in the feedback folder under ../mod/feedback/item/textarea/lib.php and ../mod/feedback/item/textfield/lib.php Under the function print_analysed section look for the foreach statement foreach($values as $value) { echo '-  ' . str_replace("\n", '
', $value->value) . ''; } I added an if statement directly above the echo to echo only if the value was not null. Code is below.... foreach($values as $value) { if($value->value != ""){ echo '-  ' . str_replace("\n", '
', $value->value) . ''; } } I did the same to both the text field and text area questions... works like a charm. Jason Label:

Post title: Suggestions / wanted features for feedback
Post description: Feedback is great module. I like and use it much. I have some suggestions / wanted features. I checked the forum and I have not found such a topic. I know Andreas is busy enough anyhow here they are: 1. Please add question type "grid" or "scale". I mean something like docs.google.com has for forms. In one question there are more rows and columns. In rows are options and in columns are weights. Weights may be open or 1,2,3.. or the Likert scale options: Strongly disagree, Disagree, Neither agree nor disagree, Agree, Strongly agree ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Likert_scale ) or Moodle Survey options: Almost never, Seldom, Sometimes, Often, Almost always. Answers are/should be stored in separate fields with names of rows (at least this is how it works in G. docs) 2. In setting-up the feedback (Edit Setting) add option (maybe in the Feedback options section) to Hide the "Not selected" No/Yes as a default option for the whole feedback (which will be default setting for the new feedback or will overwrite already set question (with warning)). In other words: additionally to the option provided for each question set the same for the whole feedback already at setting it up. 3. If the question is edited (not a newly created.. I guess you may check if the question is not the last one or question editor was reached by click on edit button) then please add in Edit Question on the bottom the new button "Save and edit next question" (next to buttons "Save changes to question" "Save as a new question" "Cancel") (and move to edit next question). 4. Pre-fill the labels field with something like SingleA1, MC2, TextS3, TextL4, Drop5 or similar for single answer, multiple choice, short, long text, drop down list etc. I mean something like: type of question+ number. The reason is that in Excel it would be meaningful to know the type of question (at least for me) without checking answers. It does not matter that user may change labels. I am guessing that most users let them empty anyway. 5. Small thing: in my installation (Moodle 2) in Templates/Use a template the text: "No templates available yet" is rendered in two lines. Just one would be enough. This is just a case when there are no templates. I just looked into the source and found that it is because of size of div.fstaticlabel. Maybe I was not clear enough. Do not hesitate to add comments, suggestions.. Thanks Miro

Forum Post: 
Post title: New question type and displaying scores or sending file through e-mail
Post description: Hi folks, I'm running MOODLE 1.9.4+ and I need a customization of the feedback module ( http://download.moodle.org/packages19/feedback_package.zip ) in order to get the following: -My students must evaluate their course instructors in several aspects. Student groups don't share all instructors and may not remember their names; so, they must select each instructor by recognizing his/her picture. They must pick and evaluate only 10 instructors (1 per subject) from a pool of over 50 instructors. Posting all instructor pictures would be a mess, so I thought about putting their names in 10 drop-down menus (1 for each subject), and by selecting a name the person's picture would automatically show up. Once the picture shows, the students can positively recognize each instructor and start individual evaluations. -Once the survey is completed, each student must receive a PDF file (matched to the MOODLE username) via e-mail containing individual scores for the course evaluations (these evaluations are applied in paper, not in MOODLE). Forum Post: 
Post title: Aggregation of Feedback results across whole Moodle site
Post description: I work for a FE College in the UK. Our moodle has around 700 courses on it, and depending on the students on the course, they are asked to complete one of four surveys using Feedback. The problem is that while the results of the feedback are visible within the scope of the course, the survey is a cross-college survey and as such we need the Feedback to be in the scope of the whole Moodle, if that makes sense. (Basically, we need details of every survey collated together on one page.) I have seen that a Feedback can be palced onto the front page of Moodle, but then it does not collect the course the student is taking, or the Teacher of the course, which we also need. Our current solution is to hack out some PHP which queries the feedback tables in the database directly, looking for instances of "Student Survey 1 - Feb 2009" or similar, and gathers results, producing a custom-build page of textual results. This page has no graphs and is not something which could easily be ported to other Moodles (id-specific user authentication and such), as well as repeating all the text in the questions, so if the questions change (which they inevitably will) the code neds changing too. Is there the possibility that Feedback can be extended to include surveys in the global scope? Ideally we need more information to be collected which we do not currently store in Moodle (such as which department the course is in, e.g. Hair and Beauty or Automotive) but that's for a different discuaaion thread. Regards,

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback: can I recover from this disaster?
Post description: I guess I used the wrong tool for the task but it occurred to me that I could use Feedback to collect data about our students submissions of their final projects but this has become a little nightmare. The idea was simple and I don't know why it shouldn't work. I created a little survey where the students had to introduce (as the answer to different questions) their first name, their last name, the name of their project and the name of the project supervisor. I thought this would save us a lot of time since we would not have to write the title of each student's project in a spreadsheet. The first problem I encountered is the organization of the data. This is my fault because I didn't check how Feedback would output the results into a spreadsheet. I thought that I could export the data into a spreadsheet in the following format: Last Name First Name Project's name Project supervisor Smith Axel How to build a... Peter Brown Seifert Nina Analysis of... Principles of Dana Peterson Peter Brown But Feedback exports the data like this: Last Name Smith Seifert García First Name Axel Nina María .... ---------- Well, that's not the real problem. I thought I would simply cut the columns for the different sections and paste them next to each other to achieve the desired format (as in the table above). I was horrified, however, when I saw that the columns are not ordered! So for instance, I would get: Last Name García Seifert Smith First Name Axel María Nina Project's name Analysis Principles of How to build a.. Project supervisor Peter Brown Peter Brown Dana Peterson So when I paste the different columns next to each other I get things totally mixed up: the Last Name from one person, the First Name from another, the title of the project from a different person, etc. What on earth is going on? I can understand that Feedback will organize the results as a single column instead of rows and columns. But why doesn't each column follow the same order? (where each position in the column for each category or question corresponds to the answer given by the same person) This doesn't make sense. The order of the column for each category seems to be totally random. I have more than 100 entries! Does this mean that I will have to access each answer through 'show responses' and add all the data by hand in a spreadsheet? Please tell me that this is not so. Is there anyway out of this mess?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback 1.9 fails to remove slashes when editing questions
Post description: When you edit a question in Feedback under Moodle 1.9, the backslashes used to escape quotes and apostrophes in the database are not being stripped out by the module. As a result, the slashes show up when you're editing the question, and are saved to the database when you save the question. To recreate the problem: 1. Create a Feedback. 2. Add a question with a quote or apostrophe in it. 3. Save the question. 4. Edit the question. The backslash should appear. 5. Save the question. The backslash is saved to the database. I added a report and proposed patch to tracker for this problem: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-15331

Post description: Andreas and others In many of our courses we use the feedback module to perform level 1 class evaluations, which work perfectly for us. Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback: add_to_log patch
Post description: Andreas, With the patches I sent you, we began giving course evaluations. One problem that came up was teachers could not view which students submitted even though the data was in the mdl_log table. This was because the cmid (course module id) was not being added. To correct this I changed line 118 of the /mod/feedback/complete.php file from: add_to_log($course->id, "feedback", "submit", "view.php?id=$cm->id", "$feedback->name"); to: add_to_log($course->id, "feedback", "submit", "view.php?id=$cm->id", "$feedback->name",$cm->id,$userid); This explicitly passes the course module and userid. I was able to use SQL to fill in the cmid since it was being stored in the URL with an UPDATE mdl_log

Post title: Unable to pull written response (comments) from feedback using SQL
Post description: Hi, We currently have 10 questions in our feedback activity over 50 courses. The last question is a text box where students are asked any other aspects of the course you would like to comment on. I would like to bulk download I am an SQL beginner at best and have managed to get the following working... except for the last question of written comments. I thought the prefix_feedback_value was the prefix that managed this.. but im wrong? Can anyone help to edit this SQL so I can also download the comments and responses from all feedback activities please? SELECT c.fullname as "Course", f.name AS "Feedback", DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(fc.timemodified), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "When", IF(i.typ = 'label', i.presentation, i.name) AS "Question", CASE WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN SUBSTRING(i.presentation,7) END AS "Possible Answers", CASE i.typ WHEN 'multichoice' THEN v.value ELSE '-' END AS "Chosen Answer Num", CASE v.value WHEN 1 THEN SUBSTRING(i.presentation, 7, POSITION('|' IN i.presentation) - 7) ELSE CONCAT("More:", v.value) END AS "Chosen Answer Text" FROM prefix_feedback AS f JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id=f.course JOIN prefix_feedback_item AS i ON f.id=i.feedback JOIN prefix_feedback_completed AS fc ON f.id=fc.feedback LEFT JOIN prefix_feedback_value AS v ON v.completed=fc.id AND v.item=i.id WHERE i.typ IN ('label', 'multichoice') Look I know its not that pretty - but I am trying! ahahahah Thanks Sammi
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Fixed SELECT c.fullname AS Course, f.name AS Feedback, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(fc.timemodified), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS CompletedAt, u.firstname AS FirstName, u.lastname AS LastName, u.username AS Username, IF(i.typ = 'label', i.presentation, i.name) AS Question, CASE WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN i.presentation ELSE NULL END AS PossibleAnswers, CASE WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN v.value ELSE NULL END AS ChosenAnswerNum, CASE -- For multichoice, extract the Nth option from the presentation text (options separated by '|') WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' AND v.value REGEXP '^[0-9]+$' THEN TRIM( SUBSTRING_INDEX( SUBSTRING_INDEX(i.presentation, '|', CAST(v.value AS UNSIGNED)), '|', -1) ) -- If MCQ but stored value isn’t numeric, just show it raw WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN CONCAT('Other: ', v.value) -- Free-text responses WHEN i.typ IN ('textarea','text') THEN v.value -- Numeric answers WHEN i.typ = 'numeric' THEN v.value ELSE NULL END AS ResponseText FROM prefix_feedback AS f JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = f.course JOIN prefix_feedback_item AS i ON f.id = i.feedback JOIN prefix_feedback_completed AS fc ON f.id = fc.feedback LEFT JOIN prefix_feedback_value AS v ON v.completed = fc.id AND v.item = i.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON fc.userid = u.id %%FILTER_CATEGORIES:c.category%% WHERE i.typ IN ('label','multichoice','textarea','text','numeric') ORDER BY c.fullname, fc.timemodified
Comment 2: SELECT c.fullname AS Course, f.name AS Feedback, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(fc.timemodified), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS CompletedAt, IF(i.typ = 'label', i.presentation, i.name) AS Question, CASE WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN i.presentation ELSE NULL END AS PossibleAnswers, CASE WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN v.value ELSE NULL END AS ChosenAnswerNum, CASE -- For multichoice, extract the Nth option from the presentation text (options separated by '|') WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' AND v.value REGEXP '^[0-9]+$' THEN TRIM( SUBSTRING_INDEX( SUBSTRING_INDEX(i.presentation, '|', CAST(v.value AS UNSIGNED)), '|', -1) ) -- If MCQ but stored value isn’t numeric, just show it raw WHEN i.typ = 'multichoice' THEN CONCAT('Other: ', v.value) -- Free-text responses WHEN i.typ IN ('textarea','text') THEN v.value -- Numeric answers WHEN i.typ = 'numeric' THEN v.value ELSE NULL END AS ResponseText FROM prefix_feedback AS f JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = f.course JOIN prefix_feedback_item AS i ON f.id = i.feedback JOIN prefix_feedback_completed AS fc ON f.id = fc.feedback LEFT JOIN prefix_feedback_value AS v ON v.completed = fc.id AND v.item = i.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON fc.userid = u.id %%FILTER_CATEGORIES:c.category%% WHERE i.typ IN ('label','multichoice','textarea','text','numeric') ORDER BY c.fullname, fc.timemodified

Post title: missing answers in feedback export
Post description: Hi all, this occurs only with a subset of items in a feedback (feedback set as not anonymous, all items set as obligatory). I cannot see what is specific about these items, only that they are separated from the others by two page breaks. The graphic representation of each item results indicates that the data seems complete. N adds up to the number of participants. The csv export however contains empty answer cells. Some do contain answers, other cells are empty. What could be the reason? Is there any way to retrieve the missing data (i.e. all answers to each of these items), maybe directly from the database ? Thanks in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The issue of missing answers seem to indicate an error in the database, but it is very simple to explain and to repair: The items referred to here are Likert scaled single choice questions. Different to the other Likert items in this feedback, here only the highest and lowest level have text labels. The levels inbetween are not labelled. In Moodle, answers are the text labels, not the numbering of the levels. So when answers are exported to a table, cells must be empty unless a level with a text label had been chosen. To repair, add labels where there are none, then export again. Existing data does not get affected.

The question is: Should this be automatically allowed to answer multiple times when it is "Anonymous" - selection above? The tip gives the idea to that way. Should the tip's text be: "If this is enabled, answering multiple (or unlimited) times is allowed ". Simple as that. And also translations must be changed to similar. Reality in functionality is that this must be selected in any case to "Yes" when multiple answers is actually allowed when this is anonymous or not. If there is "No", all participants can answer only once (and quest access does not allow doing activities like write to this forum). Next point is the instructions to this: https://docs.moodle.org/405/en/Feedback_settings " Allow multiple submissions Choose here whether or not to allow users to complete the feeback more than once. This is important when using Feedback for anonymous surveys on the front page as it will allow non-logged in users to complete the feedback." Should this be even more clear and more understandable (and of course fix the writing error "feeback" to "feedback" on text)? This leads to think that Activity completion does not work if it is anonymous and allowed answering multiple times. Reality in our Moodle version is that is works in any case. Checked on the course with quest access allowed, feedback is not possible to use. No need to say "... non-logged ...". Maybe Google Translator translates this incorrect to mean "non logged people" like meaning "quest access" because guest cannot complete the feedback or start to answer it (at least what I know and have tested). Or does this mean that if the site front page (not course) is feedback as anonymous then ...  I don't quite understand. Teachers cannot set Feedback on site front page and I see this instructions page targeted more to teachers and less to site admins like me. And if I (or anyone our site admin team) cannot understand the tip or instructions page's message, how many teachers could understand it better (well, someone can but the point to most less technical people)? B.R. Petri Hörkkö
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello there. I corrected the typo for multiple submissions in the Feedback settings page, thanks. Regarding non-logged in users completing feedback on the front page, this is explained in the FAQ: How can I allow non-logged in users to give feedback? Also, note that anyone is free to suggest improvements to the English language wording  by submitting your suggestion to the Translation site and selecting  the English (fixes) (en_fix) language pack, as described in the documentation contributing a translation .

Post title: Can Moodle record every historical feedback (which allows multiple submissions) submission without overwriting?
Post description: Hi, It seems that Moodle would only keep the latest submission (from same student) as
record for any feedbacks that allow multiple submissions. Is there anyway that
I can keep each historical submission for record, instead of letting them be
overwritten by later submission? I have checked Site administration as well as both MoodleDocs and Forum but cannot find any clue. Could anyone kindly let me know how I can
solve this issue under version 3.9.10 (Build: 20210913) ? Thanks in advance for your help! Desmond
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Came here looking for an answer to this question also! Given the age of the previous, I'm assuming this isn't possible, but if anyone has any hints would be very grateful to hear them. Many thanks.
Comment 2: I am sorry I did not see the original posting, but the answer really depends on what is being submitted. If the student is submitting a file of some sort, then you could use a database activity. There is probably a preset for this floating around. I'll take a look at my archives. Same thing if they are submitting text. However, if it is text, I would then change my recommendation for you to use the Diary plugin, which I maintain. If they are submitting images or multimedia, again you could use the Diary. Currently, Diary does not include the capability for file uploads, but it is on my TODO list to add that someday soon. I've just had too many life events here lately and have not managed to get to it.
Comment 3: Hi AL Rachels, thanks for the response. Students are not submitting files, they just complete the fields in the feedback form and click submit. Currently they can only do this once per course - any subsequent submission overrides the previous, and the earlier submission is lost. What we need is the capacity for students to submit once, that data to be stored, then student submit subsequent times, and that data to be stored also, with date stamps to distinguish which was submitted when. If you have a method would be very happy to hear about it!
Comment 4: Forgot to say - our current workaround is that we just duplicate the feedback forms so that there's now 'Submission 1', 'Submission 2', 'Submission 3', etc, for each section.  A bit inelegant, but it works!
Comment 5: I'm late to the party but I have a client system that is doing this. They get multiple submissions per student. In their case the teachers are actually submitting the feedback after a face-to-face session, and they have a custom question type that presents a droplist of enrolled students. The teacher makes multiple submissions (1 per student) and chooses the student name that the submission is for from the custom question type. I've been reverse engineering this moodle over the course of 2 years so it wouldn't surprise me if there was something that wasn't standard that enabled it. Are you saying that the multiple submissions option doesn't allow you to have multiple submissions per user (student in your case)?
Comment 6: I think from what you describe here, I would set this up as a Database activity. Database will let students make multiple submissions, and could be set to so that students can only see their submissions, if that is needed.

Post title: Moodle 4.1 feedback activity not displaying teacher tabs -- Never Mind!
Post description: I created two feedback activities  last fall using (Moodle 3.9.1 and was able to edit prior templates and update questions. The first survey ran in October 2022 and I could list participants and review the results.  In December, I upgraded to Moodle  4.1 (20221222) and subsequently migrated the entire site to a new PHP 8.1 server in February.  The second survey opened in May 2023. Everything else in the Moodle seems to be working well....but today I discovered this May feedback activity is acting oddly. I am listed (manual enrollment) as the teacher for the course when reviewing the course listing as Moodle administrator. But when I go to the course after logging in as my teacher username, I am offered tabs to edit or preview the activity questions but there is no analysis tab or list of participants who have / have not completed the survey. When reviewing feedback activities for prior years in courses where I am the teacher, I can also no longer see the results. The only administrative feedback module setting involves allowing completely anonymous feedback; this is set to no, since all Moodle users must log in to get to the feedback activities. I have the sense that I missed a setting somewhere, but I can't figure out where. Moodle: 4.1 (20221222) OS: Linux VPS running PHP 8.1 and Mariadb 10.4.19 ACTUALLY, I did figure this out eventually.  The tabs are gone from the edit page, and now are options in the feedback activity block.  I'm not sure whether there's 4.0+ documentation pointing out this shift in display thinking, but if there is, I missed it. If you read this far, thank you for your time.  Now back to our regularly scheduled chaos...
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: How did you resolve this? We've just upgraded from 3.9 and I'm having the same issue. When teachers click on the feedback activity it doesn't show them the teacher tabs as expected. The 4/4.1/4.2 videos show feedback tabs when you click on the activity so not sure what's going on...
Comment 2: Instead of tabs at the same level as "Edit questions" and "Preview Questions", the Analysis and Responses are part of the Feedback Administration block, along with Templates.
Comment 3: I see them under the Administration menu but this seems poor usability (as our admin menu normally hidden) and in any case this doesn't seem to match the images and videos shown on the Moodle site..?
Comment 4: I was able to download the responses and analysis so that I could review what I needed, but I agree that the changed location and new layout is confusing, especially since there wasn't any documentation I could find explaining this.
Comment 5: HI Clare (and Christie )- just moving this to the Feedback form where I see you already posted Clare and discovered your problem is due to your theme - I had checked the documentation and it is correct for the standard Boost theme.

Comment 3: This is the place to vote in order to get the issue solved: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70586
Comment 4: I'm finding that targeting the "Preview Questions" button with a CSS rule by using the ID doesn't work in Moodle 4.x because the ID changes every time the page is loaded or refreshed. I wrote and am using the following CSS on two self-hosted Moodle 4.1.1 sites and one Moodle 4.0.5 MoodleCloud site, all using the Boost Theme: /* hide Feedback activity Preview Questions button */ div.feedback_description div.navitem:first-of-type a.btn { display: none; } /* show Feedback activity Preview Questions button in Edit Mode */ body.editing div.feedback_description div.navitem:first-of-type a.btn { display: inline-block; } Both rules are needed. The first rule will hide the "Preview Questions" button for students, guests, facilitators, course creators, and parents. However, it also hides the "Edit Questions" button for managers and teachers (because the "Edit Questions" button is the first button in that div) making it impossible for them to edit the Feedback activity questions. The second rule displays the "Edit Questions" button when "Edit Mode" is turned on and hides it when "Edit Mode" is turned off. Although this means an extra step for managers and teachers, they can at least still edit the Feedback questions. A downside to this method is that it hides the "Preview Questions" button for facilitators so they can no longer see what questions are being asked in the Feedback activity. I haven't found a way around this. This method will only work as long as the "Preview Questions" button is in the first div with a class of "navitem" inside the div with a class of "feedback_description." If the HTML changes, the CSS will need to be updated. I'm using this as a workaround until https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70586 is resolved. It would be much better to be able to handle the display of the "Preview Questions" button via role permissions.
Comment 5: Minor correction/clarification to CSS comment for second rule: /* hide Feedback activity Preview Questions button */ div.feedback_description div.navitem:first-of-type a.btn { display: none; } /* show Feedback activity Edit Questions button in Edit Mode */ body.editing div.feedback_description div.navitem:first-of-type a.btn { display: inline-block; }
Comment 6: Inspired by your solution, as well as by https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=356299#p1437215 , I have developed a variant for Moodle 3.11 whereby the Preview icon shows for the Teacher in the editing mode (while also those Teachers who "know" will find the invisible link in the usual place, as well). I described my CSS in this comment on the Tracker (the problem is solved now for Moodle 4 and up. but not for earlier versions): https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70586?focusedCommentId=997750&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-997750 . Cheers.
Comment 7: Hi Przemek, Great idea! Your CSS code looks like it should work well in Moodle 3.11. Cam
Comment 8: Hi! In which file shall I paste this CSS code? I've tried in mod/feedback/styles.css but it doesn't work. I put it in the first line of the file. Thanks
Comment 9: Hi Julien, On my sites, which all use the Boost theme, it goes in the "Raw SCSS" field for the theme. In Moodle, go to Site administration > Appearance. In the "Themes" section, click "Boost" (or your theme name). On the Boost (or your theme) page, click the tab for "Advanced settings." Paste the CSS in the "Raw SCSS" field. Scroll down and Save changes. Clear the theme caches: Appearance > Themes: Theme selector > Clear theme caches. Test to be sure you are getting the results you want for all roles. I hope this helps! Cam
Comment 10: Thank you, it works! I use the classic theme
Comment 11: Thank you so much to Cam, Emma, Antonio and Julien - Cam for providing the CSS and everyone else for the comments and questions that helped clarify things and to remind me to vote on the issue. I implemented this today in a Moodle 4.1.1 and a Moodle 4.0.4 site and both worked perfectly.
Comment 12: Hi Julien and Bronwen, Great, thanks! I'm glad the CSS and where to put it are helpful and working well on your sites. Thanks for reporting back! Cam

Post title: Making resources hidden/orphaned but still accessible?
Post description: Moodle 3.11.4   I am struggling with making an
activity ' hidden but still
accessible ' in an orphaned section. In my previous Moodle version, I
housed my feedback question information in a section that was orphaned so
that - in an earlier, available course section - the feedback link took the
student directly to the page after 'answer the questions'. In the 3.11 Moodle
version, if I use the topics course format, that doesn't give me the ability to
subtract sections and make them available to students, but orphaned. If I use
collapsed topics, it gives me more control over adding and subtracting sections
but it also adds additional labels that aren't needed for me. If I hide the
section or topic, the student sees, 'sorry this activity is currently
hidden'. I was trying to send
the student directly to the feedback activity, without requiring him/her to
click on the 'answer the questions' button. In my previous Moodle version, the
feedback activity lived in the orphaned section, and the student was only
provided with a link to the page following 'answer the questions'. So it seems that my problem is the inability to add a section,
put accessible content in the section and next subtract the section, so
the student never sees it. This version doesn’t offer a + - section option at
the end of the page. I only used this for the feedback activity. If orphaned sections are no longer available, is there another way to offer the student a link directly to the feedback activity page?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Orphaned activities went away a long time ago. Now, you just hide the activity and then go back to the drop down menu and select Make Accessible. This is the same as orphaning - you will see now on the course page - Available but not shown on course page.
Comment 2: Thank you Emma! That's what I needed! I also needed to click site admin/advanced features/allow stealth activities to have access to 'make available' in the dropdown menu.

Post title: Feedback activity emailing ALL students and Teachers
Post description: We are running Moodle 3.9 and when the enable notification of submissions is turned on, it emails -all- students in the course and all teachers each time a new submission is made. It would be really helpful if there was a field to add specific user email addresses, separated by comma.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: One thing to check is your course permissions -- in your course Admin block, click on Users - Permissions. See which roles are enabled for "mod/feedback:receivemail" -- it may need to be just the "Teacher" role and no other roles (if I am not mistaken, if a global role is enabled there too, such as 'Manager' role, it sends to anyone on the site with that role). Then, if the "Enable notification of submissions" setting is set to Yes, then when a submission is made, this should just email "all teachers" associated with that course.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SQL query to extract data from many different feedbacks
Post description: Dear Moodle users! The problem is that I have a lot of feedbacks to extract data from and prepare one overall report. Actually it is just one (the same) feedback activity copied to over a 350 courses, where students anonymously grade the teacher from that course. So far I have been doing all of this manually, entering each course separately, extracting the feedback results to Excel and copying them to a separate file with an overall summary. But that's extremely time-consuming. Is there any way to make it automated? Any help will be much appreciated! Can someone maybe point me to the direction on how I can build an SQL query to have a one set of data from a lot of different feedbacks? I have added "Configurable Reports" block to my dashboard and I am at the "Manage reports" page (moodle/blocks/configurable_reports/managereport.php?courseid=1), but without a clue what to do next. Thanks and best regards, Kajetan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To use configurable manager you need to have some working knowledge of sql. You then write a query that pulls from the feedback tables to give you the data that you need. A couple of thoughts though...1. If your students are having to enter the course to respond to the feedback then their answers really are not anonymous as it is easy to track which student gave which answer through the logs. 2. I tend to put a single feedback on the frontpage and make it accessible to users that are not logged in. Then I make the first question a drop down where they select the course they are giving feedback for. This has two advantages - it is truly anonymous. You can pull your data for all courses at one time through the feedback activity.
Comment 2: Dear Emma, Thank you for your answer! It is very helpful and the idea of the feedback on the frontpage is brilliant, I am definitely going to implement in the future! The problem is that the previous feedbacks have to be summarized and reported. I have some working knowledge of SQL, but I do not know what paths to start to look at in the Moodle database , to build a SQL query. Any help will be much appreciated. Thanks and best regards, Kajetan
Comment 3: Have you been through the instructions - you should try and find an existing query and see if you can adjust it to meet your needs... https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports
Comment 4: I did not stumble upon this when googling the subject... Big thank you! That helps a lot.
Comment 5: Hello Kajetan, I wanted to let you know we have the same exact issue. We have approximately 150 self-paced courses with monthly reporting, and we manually go course by course and pull the spreadsheet, as well. It has become a multiple-day process to complete all of our monthly reporting requirements for grantees, course facilitators, etc. Did you end up with a SQL query that behaved as expected? Thanks for any advice.
Comment 6: Dear Carli, You will need to add the Configurable Reports block to your admin dashboard ("customize the page" in the upper right corner > "add block"). Some info on the Configurable Reports are under the link below: https://moodle.org/plugins/block_configurable_reports Also, the link provided by Emma was extremely helpful: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports Especially the coding under "Feedback Activity" chapter. We had to slightly modify the SQL code, but unfortunately I can not give you more details as I no longer have the access to the Moodle. Best regards, Kajetan

Comments associated with the post:

Probably would need examples of what you are currently using to be of further help. Also would need to know how many individuals are being rated at one time.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Suggest a "Grade" for the submission of feedback
Post description: I am a big fan of the Moodle Feedback activity and have used it in a number of small research projects centred around my e-courses - see https://www.uib.no/en/radioweb/nuclear/specialist for references. I use Feedback in anonymous mode. One of the strengths of Feedback over competing modules is the template functionality. I currently run a big new e-course over 30 course weeks. The template functionality allows me to monitor each week with minimal labour for setting up the questions. Excellent! However, my course has a challenge. Each course week contains 3 - 4 quizes that need to be passed with at least 80 %. Then the week is passed in a binary fashion - either passed or not passed. Students have to pass all 30 days. I had trouble implementing this simple algorithm in standard Moodle and implemented a custom SQL query with the "Configurable Reports" plugin. However, there could be a much simpler way of settings things up if the "Feedback" activity had a grade. I would restrict access to the week's Feedback activity until all Query modules are passed with >= 80 %, then everyone who submitted feedback would get 100 % for the feedback activity. The course total would then be the sum of all feedback activities in the course. Kind regards Martin
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The requested functionality is probably not needed. I just discovered the settings under "Activity completion" in the settings of the feedback activity. This is all what is needed. Kind regards Martin
Comment 2: Hello, I would be interested in the answer. We are creating a course where any activity genertaes a grade. This can be a participation grade (100% if completed). Does anybody have an idea how we could include feedback activities? Thank you very much for any answer! Ulrike

Forum Post: 
Post title: How do I uninstall all instances of the Feedback activity plugin?
Post description: Moodle 3.7.2 We use the Feedback activity in each Moodle course page (3500+) to allow participants to return feedback to a standard set of questions about their course. We add them in by uploading a csv set to restore from a Feedback Template page that only contains the Feedback activity but we need to remove the old instances from every page first before uploading fresh ones for the current year. Is there a way to remove all instances of this plugin in one go? Or is there a way to uninstall it then re-install it afresh? There is no 'Uninstall' option for it within the 'Manage Activities' page and just removing the Feedback folder from the Mods folder causes a site error, presumably because this is a core plugin. I have tried truncating the various mdl_feedback_xxxx tables associated with the plugin but as soon as I start importing fresh instances it repopulates the course pages with the old instances as well, resulting in multiple instances of the Feedback on each page. Is this related to the references in the 'mdl_course_modules' table ('module' column)? Hoping someone can point me in the right direction with this. Many thanks Dominique
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Dominique, the Feedback block depends on the feedback activity. So in order to delete the activity you have to unistall the Feedback block first. After that you are able to uninstall the Feedback activity. Note: If you uninstall the block either your webserver has write permissions to the moodle directory or you have to delete the folder "blocks/feedback" manually. Otherwise the block starts to install itself again. Best regards Andreas
Comment 2: Many thanks Andreas. that's just what i needed to know. Best Dominique

Forum Post: 
Post title: Hiding the "Show non-respondents" tab in feedback
Post description: Hello, I am using the Feedback activity and need my Non-Editing Teachers to be able to see the responses (and the users who did them, so cannot be anonymous), but not see the "Show non-respondents" tab.  Reason being, I will have about 30 odd Feedback activities on the course, but users will only be able to see the one relevant to them (via using restricted access).  Currently the Non-respondents tab shows all users enrolled on the course and I do not want this to be available, as the non-editing teachers should only see the users relevant to their course. I have tried playing with the permissions, but if I hide reports to them, they cannot see the Responses either. Any help very much appreciated!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you have access to custom CSS in your theme, you can add 
```text
#page-mod-feedback-view a[title="Show non-respondents"] {display: none;}
```
 ...with the caveat that it will hide it for you too! If you don't have access to custom CSS, you can go to Site Administration > Appearance > Additional HTML and add the following in the box 'Within HEAD'... 
```text
<style>


#page-mod-feedback-view a[title="Show non-respondents"] {display: none;}


</style>
```
 😁
Comment 2: Hi Jon Thank you so much!  Will try it now.
Comment 3: Hi Jon It worked on the main page but as soon as I clicked on the 'Show responses' tab the 'Show non-respondents' tab appears again.  Do I need to put different html in the When BODY is opened box?
Comment 4: Take out the `#page-mod-feedback-view` bit. I was deliberately being very specific so that it didn’t have a unintentional impact elsewhere, but there won’t be many links with that title so it should only affect Feedback module.
Comment 5: That worked.  Thank you so much for your help and quick responses!
Comment 6: Great, pleased it worked 👍 Can you humour me though (sorry!). There is a (very small) risk that now or in the future, there may be another link with that title in another part of Moodle. With this CSS, it will not display ANY link with that title, not just the ones in the Feedback activity... which is why I gave you the original code. Use this instead - it will only target the Feedback activity: 
```text
.path-mod-feedback a[title="Show non-respondents"] {display: none;}
```
Comment 7: Yeah no problem! Swapped it over and it also works.  So, this code targets just the feedback activity?
Comment 8: Yes, that’s what the `.path-mod-feedback` bit does. Without that, any link that had the title of "Show non-respondents" in any activity would be hidden.

Post title: Compare pre and post evaluation results in analysis
Post description: I have a pre and post evaluation in my course, I want to be able to have the analysis show each users pre and post course analysis together without having to go to each one and slowly pull everything together? Comment 1: I have same problem in my couse.  Does anyone have idea of how to make pre and post evaluation for students?
Comment 2: I ran into a similar problem using Totara, Moodle's cousin. I had an activity for pre, post, and open feedback (comments) for each course. I would export the results from each activity into an Excel spreadsheet from the Analysis tab with the raw data, giving me three spreadsheets. Using VBA in Excel I created forms and macros to merge the three spreadsheets, format them, analyze the data, and create a new worksheet with comparison results and charts. Yes, it is the long way around, but it works.

Post description: Hi I've been comparing feedback tool and questionnaire tool for Module Evaluation surveys. I am assuming not but if there is a way it would be good to know. Can a question be locked, as part of a template, so that course owners can add more questions but not delete core questions? I am assuming not, but again, if there is a way it would be good to know. Questionnaire Tool provides a printable version: could there also be a printable version of the Feedback Tool? (for accessibility purposes, or for spares if students don't have devices with them). (and obviously a printed version isn't compatible with branching logic). This is a whole bigger ask, but could there be a way of aggregating reports so that category managers / people with higher level permissions could download multiple reports / multiple results as combined CSVs? If Moodle could do a little more on the data handling side it would be powerful. Plug-in/integration suggestions welcome (cheap!). Grateful for tips/suggestions on any of the above. Amber

Comment 1: Another potential improvement: Could the downloadable results file have the courseID (or some other identifier) in the filename? That would help with the data-handling.
Comment 2: I am also trying to use Feedback in a way that would allow me to export the information in a meaningful way, particularly with non-users who will answer questions anonymously prior to being enrolled. In exporting the data I noticed two things: A "Response Number" was created but it incremented *backwards* -- that is, a person responded last night.  Her response was marked as Response 1.  Then another person responded this morning.  When I exported again, this morning''s response was marked as Response 1 and last night's as Response 2.  This is NOT going to work in any database or other tool. So I thought I would try to add a question to the Feedback that would tag the responses -- such as a date.  I noticed that there is a question type called "Information" which said it could supply the course name, the course category, or the date responded.  Great!  Except the date option wasn't available -- only course and category. (I am in 3.3 if that matters here). I suppose I could require my guests to supply a date but that would be too various (people enter dates in all sorts of random formats) and also not as useful as a system-generated time/date stamp would be.
Comment 3: When you export to Excel, that info will be there...
Comment 4: This is the excel export,  No date. Backwards response #
Comment 5: Want to follow this. I would really like a single, global Feedback for a whole category of courses. I wish Feedback could put in the course name automatically (like a token) to the submissions. Then I could download all responses and still be able to filter/sort to a particular course. Is there a way to use a single Feedback activity in a slew of courses?
Comment 6: We use the Feedback activity extensively for standardised evaluations amongst c 1500 courses per semester and we feed the data out to an analytics tool. I don't think this is really feasible through the web interface - we do it using the raw data. There's a complex set of relationships that are intended to obfuscate who the respondent actually is for anonymity, but you can indeed map each response back to the specific user if you need to through linking various tables (we have done this because one project wanted to compare evaluation feedback with course outcomes for each student - so we had to "unanonymise" them, combine them with completion and grade book statistics and then reanonymise the whole lot again. But to be honest, since Feedbacks can be used for lots of different things, it is tricky to be able to capture all the data without holding elsewhere a list of course module numbers that refer to the specific feedback activities we deploy centrally as evaluation forms. I was considering forking the feedback activity, to create something specifically called "evaluation feedback" so that for people like us who want to know the answers to the same set of questions to measure student experience across the whole institution, nobody else could tinker with them. But to answer some of the OP 's original questions: No, we could not find a way of "branching" questions. Yes, it can be locked at deployment time, but no, that means they can't edit it at all. We created a "course evaluation extra" feedback for if they wanted to ask additional questions on the basis that responses to these questions would not be extracted to the learning analytics system. But as I say, most of what we do is done a. by using data from the Moodle database rather than pre-built reports within the Feedback module itself, and b. the analysis is done by a back end stats package that we transfer data to. Jock

Post title: Behavior changed; non-anonymous now overwrites previous
Post description: I was using the Feedback activity last year with Moodle 3.2 in a speech class. I set it up so students could submit multiple feedbacks (non-anonymous), and I was using it so that they could evaluate the other students' speeches. This worked flawlessly. I got all the submissions, downloaded them to Excel, and could go through them. I could then give students points for the evaluations. This year I've upgraded to Moodle 3.3 and used the same Feedback activity: multiple submissions and non-anonymous. Now it seems that each submission overwrites the previous submission. Why was this changed? And more importantly: What can I do now that this no longer works? It doesn't appear that there is any other activity that makes this type of activity possible.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ryan, As far as I can recall, non-anonymous feedbacks have always overwritten the last one entered by the person. I've gotten around this in the past by setting them to be anonymous and then having a field where the person enters their name. You could also try the Workshop activity for peer assessment, or use the Questionnaire plugin which explicitly includes this feature.
Comment 2: Chad, Thanks! I'll look into the Workshop or Questionnaire (or modifying the Feedback so they fill out their own names). However, I definitely did use this one year ago on Moodle 3.2. I've compared the two assignments from the two courses, and they are exactly the same in every aspect except for the students registered. The old one has ALL the responses but this new one only has the latest, so something definitely changed. Cheers!

Post title: This forum post has been removed
Post description: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes - add the Feedback to the Main Menu block, take a note of the URL , and then hide the Main Menu block. Give people the link to the feedback activity and it will work as expected. As an alternative to hiding the Main Menu block, some themes allow blocks to be displayed in a special part of the footer, which allows blocks moved into that area to be visible only to admin users. You can add a link to the Feedback in the top menu or elsewhere. Check whether you need to change the setting for "Allow full anonymous" - it needs to be set to "yes" to permit non-logged in users on the front page to complete a feedback activity.
Comment 2: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 3: If you turn editing on, you will be able to add a Main Menu block to the front page. In that block, you can add activities and resources. Those activities and resources will still be available via the URL even if the Main Menu block is hidden. See docs at https://docs.moodle.org/en/Main_menu_block

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback Report for multiple classes
Post description: How can one generate a Feedback report for all Feedback Surveys without having to export each? I have two types of Feedback Surveys and need to pull a report for multiple (hundred's) classes.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Are these sitewide Feedbacks, or is it a separate feedback activity in each course?
Comment 2: The Feedbacks are separate activities in each course.
Comment 3: You would have to use something like Configurable Reports for this.  Something that queries the database directly.
Comment 4: I am a Moodle novice and not a programmer. So, I am not familiar with anything that might query the Moodle database. I see reports in Moodle and also see the Feedback Analytics which can be exported to Excel but, it seems a bit crazy that I should have to export manually for so many classes. However, I am under the gun and need to get the Feedback information so, crazy as it seems I may be reduced to doing that just to satisfy superiors at this point. Any help is tremendously appreciated.
Comment 5: There is a plugin called configurable reports that makes it a little easier but you still need to be familiar with the database.  Without the time to gain that knowledge, sadly, you will need to export individually from each course. Next time, if you are using the same survey in multiple courses, create it on the front page and then send it to the courses (there is a feedback option for that).  That way, I think you will get all the answers in one place.
