Post title: Dependency question that jumps to completion message
Post description: I would like to set up a feedback where I can have the feedback end when a student answers "No" to a specific question. For example: Do you use a smartphone? Yes (will move to next question.) No (Jumps to the completion message)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi David, You can do what you want using both the Feedback and Questionnaire activities. There are a couple of things you need to do. Put a page break right after a conditional question like this or it will not work. Be careful with capitalization and spelling when doing this with Feedback activities, as Yes and yes are not the same. Let me know if you would like an example of each.
Comment 2: Hi Al, Thank your for information. I think I have thing working the way I want them now. I needed to rethink how I wanted to ask the questions and in which order.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback : conditional questions and guest access
Post description: Hi Mary A rather belated post on this topic, I have worked through the FAQ and it works great.  I have however found what I think is an issue using Moodle 3.12 and as I am new to the whole the reporting issues and realising 3.2 is imminent.  I though I would check with you first. When a page break is used and all fields are required it is impossible to navigate (using the previous button) back to the first page without filling in the required fields of the second page. This creates some confusion particularly when using conditional fields on the second page based on field content on the first page, made worse if the user has chose the wrong answer on the first page and cannot understand why the field expected does not appear on the second page. If any of that makes sense? Thanks Ross
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Ross. Is this with a guest user or any user? (Looking at the title of this thread, it's about guest users)
Comment 2: Hi Mary I working with Guest feedback and that's where it became apparent, but it fails with authenticated users in the same way. I came across what may be a second issue with guest access to feedbacks. problem 1 A guest fills in the first page of a feedback and proceeds to a second page. It appears Moodle saves the first page entries to the feedback table linked to the guest account. The guest either cancels the feedback, navigates to another page or closes moodle without saving the feedback. When another guest accesses moodle the previous guests entries are visible to them. Even after closing moodle  and clearing history and cookies. The information seems to be getting stored with the guest account rather than an anonymous feedback. It would seem moodle is treating the guest user as a standard authenticated user by allowing them to continue where they last left the feedback. Problem 2 An extension of the original issue unable to navigate forward or backward through page breaks if there are required fields. When the second guest is presented with the entries of a previous guest who has aborted their multi page feedback where required fields are present on all or some pages. Being unable to navigate forward or back through pages to clear the other guests entries forces them to abort the feedback, possibly rendering all future feedbacks of this instance unlikely unless some bright spark works out what's going on. I have tried this on several feedbacks and the fault is reproducible. Many Thanks  Ross
Comment 3: Hi again. I've split your thread to make it clearer what the discussion is about and to see if we can get other experiences on here. For myself, I would expect that if another guest starts an unfinished feedback, the previous guest entries are available to them, but let's see what others think.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moving exist feedback
Post description: Hi Moodlers, As the title, can I move the exist feedback to another course page with the same URL /ID? Thanks in advance. Raymon Akbar
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I found here https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=195565 but It might change the URL/ID for an activity/feedback.
Comment 2: It will change the id because it will be a different instance of the feedback.  You cannot "move" a feedback around, you can only import or restore it to the new course which effectively creates a copy of the feedback with a new id so it is unique to that course.

Forum Post: 
Post title: sending the feedback to course teacher
Post description: hello, i searching now of a module or activities which allow the student to write his course overall feedback to the teacher course directly. is there any way to do that ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Feedback module - part of core but disabled by default.  Enable in manage activities.
Comment 2: in this case i must assign the teacher to teacher role, but i need to send these feedback to some one not has any role in the moodle.
Comment 3: This is how I handle teacher evaluations:  Create a feedback on the front page of the site.  Set it to be anonymous.  Add permissions to authenticated user and guest to complete the feedback.  I make the first question a dropdown list asking the name of the teacher they are evaluating.  Once it has closed, download to excel.  Here you can filter by teacher and then I just send them their results.  Works really well and students like that it is anonymous.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Non-anonymous feeback and multiple submissions problem
Post description: Hello, after upgrading to Moodle 3.1.1 the behaviour of the feedback activity seems to have changed: Settings: - Record user names: User's name will be logged and shown answers - Allow multiple submissions: yes We use this szenario for students to book certain courses via multiple choice elements. Back in M2.8 users could submit their answers and reopen the activity to review their selection or make changes to the selection -> initial answers where shown to the users. Now in M 3.1.1 when users submit a feedack and repopen the activity they do not see their initial selection and if they submit the form a second time a second response will be created. Can anybody confirm? Is that a bug or is it an intended feature? Thanks and regards Tobias Moodle 3.1.1 (Build: 20160711)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you tried it with multiple submissions turned off?
Comment 2: Same problem. If multiple submissions are turned off, they can't complete the questionnaire at all. This is a major issue for my moodle. I'm using feedback as a portfolio for students to accumulate data into over the course of the year. Worked fine last year. This year 1500 students have entered their data and now can't access it to update it.
Comment 3: Thanks for your comment. Unfortunately turning off multiple submissions simply results in letting the students only submit a feedback once. No changes of initial submission possible. I opened a tracker entry: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-56370
Comment 4: Thanks for submitting the tracker entry, Tobias. An option to configure it so it works either way would have been a useful upgrade, but changing the behaviour of existing feedbacks  like this is not good.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Other User Roll
Post description: Hello all. I am in need of some assistance with the Other User (s) in courses. At
our company there there are many departments with many managers that
are allowed to create and assign courses. We are a world wide company
and with that there are over 100+ user s with rolls like Department Manager, Site Manager, Course Creator, and so on. In
my department I have created a Feedback form using the Feedback module.
When one of the employees of my department fills out the Feedback form
(used for evaluation and progress in their job), it emails me, the
instructor of that department. However it also emails ALL of the 100+ Other User s that do not need or want this sent to them. Question: How can I limit these Other User s from a course and be able to control who gets the email notification? Any help is greatly appreciated and welcome. Thanks for your time, Dennis
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You could override those roles on that activity so they don't receive emails. In the administration block of the activity you can click on the permissions link to change what the permissions are on that activity.
Comment 2: Thank you very much of this info. I did not realize that could be done. So if add all roles to Prohibited, then no one would get the emails. Guess that means that I could create a new role, say "feedbackemailuser" and add that role to only the people intended to receive this when the form is submitted? Correct? The help is very much appreciated. Dennis

Post description: Maybe it's just me, but I can't find a way to add Feedback on the main front page . I can add the Feedback block. But how do i create a Feedback form from the front page that is not tied to any course, and can be filled by anonymous / guest users ? Thanks for the help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Add the Main menu block and add your Feedback from there.
Comment 2: Thanks. I was able to find it before reading this comment. However, i'm still having issues with receiving email notification. I have added an admin account as "teacher" in Feedback Admin > Locally assigned roles. I have also checked that teacher and non-teacher roles (default) have permission to receive email notification. I receive email for other things like for backups and updates, so i assume it's not the mail server . What else can i do to troubleshoot this please? Thanks.
Comment 3: This is sorted. I just had to make sure that all settings are correct. I have been playing with different combinations earlier, my bad. BTW , is it possible to send the content of the "feedback" by email and not just a notification that the form has been completed? The purpose of having it in front page is to have a contact form to which we can respond if needed.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Automated reminders?
Post description: Hi all, is it possible for Moodle somehow to send non-respondents an automated reminder a certain number of days or hours before a feedback activity's end time? The message would say something like, "Dear [firstname], please submit your responses to [feedback activity name] before [feedback activity end date and time]." Does anyone know how this can be done?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Closest I can think of is using completion tracking and conditional access to show a label at the appropriate time with that text to people who haven't yet completed the activity. I don't think there is a way to send an email though, unless there is some way to control group access based on activity completion and then set a timed forum post to go out to people in the group of noncompleters.
Comment 2: Hi Albert, The plugin Event Reminder may do what you want. This plugin is only released for Moodle 2.9 or lower, not for Moodle 3. With kind regards, Hartmut

Forum Post: 
Post title: Changing Question and Submissions setting defaults
Post description: Hello, I am trying to change the defaults of the Question and Submissions settings in the Feedback Settings. More specifically, I'd like to modify the "Record User Names" and "Allow Multiple Submissions" defaults, since I have many courses' feedback to set up this way. Can anyone tell me how? I have looked it up and looked everywhere in the Administrator settings, and I didn't see it. Thanks in advance Cheers Joe
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hmm... The Docs for the Feedback Module state: "The feedback module has additional settings which may be changed by an administrator in Administratio.n > Site administration > Plugins > Activity modules > Feedback " However, the only option I see when there is whether or not to allow anonymous surveys on the front page . Unless there is a reason to have no ability to set defaults, maybe you can create Moodle Tracker asking to give admins the option to set defaults for this module. * In the meantime, consider downloading the Sharing Cart plug in. Then you can create a 'template' that you'd like to base all of your Feedback modules on and save this template to your sharing cart. Then whenever you need to add a new Feedback module, just turn on the Sharing Cart block, and download the Feedback template into that course. Nice an simple! *

Forum Post: 
Post title: Anonymous Feedback possible without guest login?
Post description: Hello, we have Moodle: 2.8.5 and want to implement an anonymous feedback with moodle. Done so far: created a feedback activity on the frontpage set it to anonymous feedback. The problem: Only people that login as guest can answer the feedback, but the guest users can see all courses and course sections We want to prevent that guest users see the courses and course section Questions: Is the full anonymous feedback on the frontpage possible without to login as guest? If not, it is possible to hide all contens in moodle from guests?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes, there are a couple of other steps. Go into permissions for the feedback and make sure that guest and authenticated user are both selected to complete the feedback.  They should not have to login as guest.  They should just be able to click on it and complete. Also, check your front page settings to see what the default role is for people on the front page.

Forum Post: 
Post title: add question with dependency
Post description: hi i'm still new in moodle. Now i'm making a feedback in my moodle. But my boss really need to make it dependent each other, for example: Q1. Do you smoke ? Yes -> go to Q2 No -> go to Q3 i've tried to make it but it's not work. Is there anybody could show me how to do that. Thank you very much....
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, here the text from the help button: It is possible to show an item depending on the value of another item. Here is an example. First, create an item on which another item will depend on. Next, add a pagebreak. Then add the items dependant on the value of the item created before. Choose the item from the list labelled "Dependence item" and write the required value in the textbox labelled "Dependence value". The item structure should look like this. Item Q: Do you have a car? A: yes/no Pagebreak Item Q: What colour is your car? (this item depends on item 1 with value = yes) Item Q: Why don't you have a car? (this item depends on item 1 with value = no) ... other items I hope it helps. Best regards Andreas
Comment 2: Thank you Andreas, it's really help.. Best Regards, Reza
Comment 3: I know this is old, but I have encountered this problem - despite very careful attention to the instructions, and to spelling, I cannot get the 'No' choice to jump to a different question. The client must click through all the intermediate questions. If they select the 'Yes' choice, they are presented with the proper question. It would really be useful to have the user able to skip ahead about 30 questions, when the answer is 'No' - but really it is no different than just selecting N/A to the dependant question, and ignoring the dependance feature altogether.... FWIW, none of the intermediate questions are marked "required" thx Ken
Comment 4: Do you have a page break before the question that you want No to jump to?  Can you post screenshots of that question?
Comment 5: Yes; what Emma says and also take a look at the section Dependence item and dependence value in Building Feedback
Comment 6: (old thread, but still relevant) The problem for me is that you're forced to have an equivalent question (or label etc.) on every level, which is not very user friendly. The way it is now, I can't just skip ahead to the next main question or the end-of-survey-message.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Dependency of Feedback on Course
Post description: I am using Moodle 2.9 Version. I am creating a course of type Lesson . I know how to use feedback module. I want to make a condition that after course completion Feedback will shown & without Feedback, course is not completed. It means after completion of all pages one Feedback page will open & after filling of that feedback form, it means course is now completed. So please help me to create dependency of Feedback on course & help me to configure without filling feedback, Course doesn't completed. Please help. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If I understand you - Student completes all activities in a course, making the course 'complete' except for the feedback - which would not be visible until all those activities are completed. BUT you don't want the system to actually show the course as complete until the feedback is done. I would say you can't base the feedback release on course completion then, you need to use the conditional release tool for the feedback activity, where the conditional release is based on a whole series of other activities already being completed. You can then base the course completion on the feedback activity being done as well.
Comment 2: Thanks Richard. May you please describe what you want to say. Are you talking about any conditional module. Condition Release Tool means ? Please help me to provide me the way to add condition on Conditional Release Tool or provide path. Thanks Nishant
Comment 3: https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Conditional_activities
Comment 4: Thanks Richard Oelmann .
Comment 5: 1.  Set up completion settings on each activity in the course. https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Activity_completion 2.  Add Restriction to Feedback https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Conditional_activities 3.  Set your Course Completion settings dependent on Feedback being completed.
Comment 6: Thanks Emma Richardson .

Post title: Export answers to Feed-back activity into an Excel in a sensible way
Post description: Hello, Though the Feed-back activity allows to export the answers to an Excel spreadsheet, the way it is exported makes it difficult to analyze it. Example: imagine this very simple feed-back to measure degree of satisfaction at the end of a certain course: 1. Question 1: who has been your teacher? The user has to choose between two possibilities: John, Theresa 2. Question 2: How was he/she? The user has to choose between two possibilities: Good Bad. Because of the way the Excel is exported, we will know how many students had John and how many had Theresa. We will also know how many students think their teacher is good and how many think he/she is bad. But we won't know how many students think John is a good teacher. This would be solved if the export to Excel just follows basic table structure like this ANSWERS Question 1 Question 2 student 1 John Good student 2 John Bad student 3 Theresa Good This Excel could just be downloadable from the "Show responses" tab. This is just a suggestion. Our teachers usually miss this. Thanks, Gabriel
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Good points - although if you are using Feedback just in one course and  you set your course to groups, and John's class is in one group and Theresa's class is in another group, you can download two separate Excel files with the results just for those students and then easily see what they thought of their respective teachers. (I am moving this thread to the Feedback forum.)
Comment 2: Hi Gabriel, please have a look at the second excel-sheet. There is one row for each student. Best regards Andreas
Comment 3: Thank you Andreas, this is exactly what I was looking for. Sorry for wasting your time, I did not notice the second tab called "detailed". Thanks, Gabriel

Forum Post: 
Post title: Including Submission Results in Email
Post description: As most people know, the feedback module is one of the few modules that guests can access.  As a result, it can be used for many purposes, such as a quick survey, contact form, etc.  One feature that is a bit difficult is the fact that the results are randomized and the email notifications do not include the submission values.  This makes it difficult for using it as a contact form.  For example, if a guest fills out the form and submits it, the admin gets an email saying the form was completed.  The link in the email sends the admin to the list of submissions, but since the submissions are randomized, it makes it nearly impossible to determine which one was just sent. Before Moodle 2, the Questionnaire module was handy for this because it sent all the form data in the email.  However, this cannot be used anymore with guests.  Joseph's suggestion is to use LimeSurvey, but I find it to be a bit cumbersome and also I don't want many to many systems for my sites. As a result, I created a patch for the Feedback module that will send the results of the feedback in the email.  Only two files were edited: lib.php (patch attached) complete_guest.php (only one line edited - shown below) Edit for complete_guest.php: Line 256, Moodle 2.7.1, replace 
```text
                feedback_send_email_anonym($cm, $feedback, $course, $userid);  //Original
```
 With 
```text
                feedback_send_email_anonym($cm, $feedback, $course, $new_completed_id);  //Edit
```
 It works well for us, however, I would appreciate any feedback as well as some help with fine tuning it. With the patch, every feedback submitted sends email to the "teacher" of the courses.  I would like to add one additional setting in the initial settings of the feedback so the person setting it up can decide whether to have the submissions sent to the teacher in an email or keep the original functionality. Maybe something like Include submission values in email (default no) Once this is in, I can make the appropriate changes in the two files to honor the setting. Any "feedback" would be appreciated (no pun intended... well, maybe some pun was intended) Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I was hoping someone would chime in about this, but no one did.  I am giving this discussion a little "bump" in hopes someone can throw their two cents in.
Comment 2: Hi Paul, Have you considered to use the Dataform plugin in your front page ? I cannot tell for sure whether this is possible at all as I haven't tried it yet, but I know that the plugin is highly customizable. With kind regards, Hartmut
Comment 3: Thanks Hartmut, No, I haven't tried the Dataform plugin myself.  My installation already has many plugins and I didn't want to add any more. I have been using my modification for quite some time now with success.  I was hoping someone else would try it out and offer suggestions/opinions. Best, Paul
Comment 4: Paul, I tried your patch and I like the ability to include the results in an email. That makes very convenient for those needing the data. This also taught me to apply my first patch.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Customizing Completion Tracking
Post description: I need to find in the code where the "Moodle Level" activity completion tracking is being set. The last page of a Feedback activity has a submit button that when selected (given the correct activity settings) sets the activity to complete which is displayed as a checkmark in the box on the course/view.php page. The page that sets the completion appears to be complete.php. Can someone identify the line(s) of code where the completion is set? Can someone indicate where in the database the activity completion status is stored that enables the activity to display the checkmark when completed? Thanks!!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Found the table.field. course_module_completion.completionstate
Comment 2: The code I was looking for is: // Update completion state $completion = new completion_info($course); if ($completion->is_enabled($cm) && $idevplan->completionsubmit) { $completion->update_state($cm, COMPLETION_COMPLETE); } In case that helps someone else looking for the same thing. Cheers!
Comment 3: The current code sets a Feedback activity to be completed when submitted. Why would you need to change this? Joseph
Comment 4: Hi Joseph - We have done a good bit of customization to the plugin to meet our specific requirements. We have added a piece where we track if a user's supervisor has reviewed the feedback. We want the activity to remain incomplete until the user has reviewed their feedback with their supervisor in an offline meeting. The user then manually goes in and flags the activity as reviewed by their supervisor. We are setting the activity's completion status based on the completion of that offline meeting setting. Hope that makes sense... -Rob
Comment 5: Thanks for the explanation.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback with Teaching Staff
Post description: In order to gather some information from some Teaching Staff, I have created a feedback activity full of questions. However, because all of the staff are enrolled in the course as 'non-editing teachers', they do not see the ' Answer the questions... ' link. To make matters worse, they all saw the 'Preview' button  (magnifying glass) and then filled out all of their details on that. When they eventually press 'Continue', none of their responses are stored. Is their any way to make this work with 'non-editing teachers'  or do I need to re-do the feedback activity in a new course where all of the staff have the role 'student'. thanks ... Tim
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I found the solution in a previous post from Andreas Grabs. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=213257 To allow teacher & non editing teachers to complete feedback ....you have to override the permission in the feedback-instance its self. 1) Go into your course 2) Click on your feedback you want to use for your teachers 3) Click on "Permissions" inside the block "Settings" 4) In the dropdown list "Advanced role override" choose "Teacher" or how ever your teacher role is named 5) Look for "mod/feedback:complete" and set it to "Allow" 6) Click on "Save changes"
Comment 2: Hi Tim. U are giving wonderful information..it is so use  for me
Comment 3: Thanks for the heads-up on this -it is now in the Feedback FAQ

Forum Post: 
Post title: Guest access and Feedback functionality very misleading for Teachers
Post description: Using 2.4.3+ Guest access and Feedback functionality is very misleading for Teachers. The documentation is clear in that Guests can only use Feedback successfully on the front page of the Moodle yet, when Guests log in and access a Feedback within a course, by default, Moodle allows the Guest to click on the preview icon, fill out the form and click Continue.   The Guest doesn't necessarily know this is only a preview and that the results will not be saved.  There is no error or warning message and it appears to let the Guest complete the Feedback which is misleading to the Guest and the Teacher administering the site. I have found a way to get around this by modifying the Guest role so they are not able to view Feedbacks but my question is why would a guest even be allowed to access/preview a Feedback in a course if the functionality is disabled here?  What purpose does this serve if they cannot save results?  If there is a use-case for this, It might be useful to implement a warning at the very least so that guests are aware they are only previewing the Feedback and not actually completing the feedback.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Susan, thank you for this post. You are right the "Continue" button could be some confusing. I think I could change that to a "Back" button. Would that be better? Best regards Andreas
Comment 2: Changing the continue button to something like 'Close Preview' might help. Although, I still think some sort of warning might be warranted here.  I think a pop up when the Guest clicks on the preview icon would be ideal.  Something like "This is only a preview, any changes made in this form will not be saved" Or, having the Guest preview capability set in the Feedback settings with the default being off.  Then those that really need this capability can turn it on accordingly. Thank-you for your consideration!

Forum Post: 
Post title: View feedback in one page
Post description: Hi, I'm using moodle feedback 2.4. and i also use a condition if answer yes go to question no 2. to do this i need to add page break. but i want my feedback question all display in one page. how can i do that?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You can't do that. The Dependencies feature of the Feedback module needs page breaks to be inserted between each "dependent" item, as is clearly explained in the online Help: First, create an item on which another item will depend on. Next, add a pagebreak. Then add the items dependent on the value of the item created before. Choose the item from the list labelled "Dependence item" and write the required value in the textbox labelled "Dependence value". Joseph

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 1.9 Feedback calculation of averages
Post description: We’ve been using the Feedback module for some time. Up to now, the Feedbacks are set for single submission, using: · ‘Required’  ‘Multiple choice (rated) single answer allowed (dropdown list); and · Optional ‘Longer text answers’. This setup works entirely reliably and the exported Excel workbook provides calculated averages for the numerically rated questions – which is what we need. The calculation of averages is based on the ‘requirement’ for each respondent to give a numerically rated value before the Feedback will be accepted when ‘Submit’ is selected. If a ‘required’ answer has been omitted, the individual’s responses are no accepted, and the user is prompted to supply a numerically-rated answer. For every numerically-rated answer, the average is calculated as the sum of each numerical value x the frequency of that value/the total number of people submitting responses to the Feedback. I’ve just introduced a different style of Feedback set to allow ‘Multiple submit’. This means that students can complete one Feedback progressively through an 8-week residential course. When they select ‘Submit’, their answers are recorded and saved. They can then re-enter the Feedback to add new responses and, if they wish, amend earlier responses in the light of course developments. Again, the Feedback employs a mixture of ‘Multiple choice (rated) single answer allowed (dropdown list); and ‘Longer text answers’. · However, it is not practical to set the Multiple choice (rated) questions to ‘Required’. · If that were done, then in, say, week one, all the students would have to give ratings for every week covered by the Feedback in order to ‘Submit’, even though the course had not yet dealt with the topics to which the questions related. Unfortunately, the Feedback calculation of averages does not cope with unreliable human beings! For each numerically-rated question, the average is the sum of each numerical value x the frequency of that value/the total number of people submitting responses to the Feedback. The algorithm does not take account of the number of people answering the question . The two are not necessarily then same, and therefore the automatically-calculated averages are not correct. Our need for this new style of using the Feedback module will increase in importance. So… Is it possible to modify the Feedback module to calculate averages based on the number of respondents to each question, rather than the maximum number of respondents to the Feedback as a whole?
Comments associated with the post:

It is hidden by default, and when a teacher wants to give the survey, s/he makes it visible. Comments associated with the post:

Comment 4: Hi Nancy, I don't know that I understood all right. I think you have to place a feedback inside the moodle frontpage. There you have to give the needed rights to complete this feedback. Forum Post: 
Post title: How to obtain individual Trainer feedback results
Post description: Hi. I am part of an organisation that has 2000 employees attending a mixture of face to face and elearning modules as part of their induction training. We induct between 400-600 new employees each year. I have set up feedback forms for each face to face session throughout the learners induction on moodle. Each face to face will most probably have a different trainer. What I want to be able to do is now measure the feedback forms via the trainer who ran each course so we can measure knowledge and satisfaction. I understand that I could group learners into a group for each trainer, but that learner won't have the same trainer for each face to face. And I can't have lots of different feedback forms to suit each trainer either. Is there a way to pick from a drop down list, who the trainer was on the face to face so that I can then pull responses by trainer? Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I just add a drop down list of all teachers and have the student pick which one they had. I have found that to be the simplest way to accomplish what you are looking for.
Comment 2: Hi Emma, thanks so much for your response. I have been able to add the drop down box to the feedback forms so that learners can pick the trainer who ran the session. From a line manager point of view, if I wanted to them pull feedback analysis via trainer, how would I do this? As when I look at the responses and analysis it just shows how many times a learner has picked their name. The only way I know would be to add each learner to a group for each trainer, but the administration behind this is too much for us. As 1 learner may see 4 trainers. If you have any further advice, I'd really appreciate it. Simon
Comment 3: I always export all the responses to Excel and then filter them there - that way I can filter for each teacher and then I just copy those results over to separate sheet that I can then share with the teacher. You can export right from the feedback activity.  You will get two sheets in the spreadsheet - the second sheet has the detailed responses.

Post title: Feedback Template "public" tick box
Post description: Hello, I've just upgraded to 2.1.3 and would like to use the Feedback plugin for many courses. Our eval form is the same for all courses so I'd like to save a template for re-use. My problem is that the "public" tick box doesn't appear when saving a template. Do I need to enable that option somewhere? Thanks, Dave
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: We have also same problem. In roles it has been enabled to teacher (I think it's default), but when checking the role ability to create public template in administration, the system says, that I have to enable the capability. We have Moodle 2.2.4
Comment 2: Hi Sami, sitewide templates are related to a global context . So you can not give some rights at course level. You have to give the right global. One way could be to create a new empty role "templatecreator". For this role allow the creation of public templates. Then put all teachers you want to have the right into this role global. Best regards Andreas
Comment 3: Just in case anyone gets to this thread from Google, I have documented how to do this here: Template creator
Comment 4: Hi Dave, the feature to use sitewide templates is available in Moodle 2.2.x upwards. In 2.0 to 2.1 it was disabled. Best regards

Forum Post: 
Post title: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
Post description: Hi, I have a course with several teachers. I need to collect feedback from them, so I was trying to use the Feedback resource, but I  wasn't able to reach the desired result. After creating the Feedback, teachers were not allowed to answer it. I tried to use a custom role assignment, particularly for the " Complete a feedback " capability. But it seems I can't choose the role "teacher" to add to the list of allowed roles. The documentation page says that this capability is restricted to the default role of a student. Does anyone have a suggestion as how to achieve my desired result: Enable teachers (including me, the feedback creator, probably) the ability to answer it.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Just make a new course -add your teachers to it as students and make the feedback there. They will be able to complete it no problem.
Comment 2: I could do that, but I was hoping for a way to do this collaboration inside the same course. This suggestion would mean that I'd have potentionally to reflect all the course structure with a parallel, teacher-only structure. Thanks for the suggestion anyway, Fadi
Comment 3: Hi Fadi, if you already have the teacher in a single course it should be possible to use a feedback inside this course. Can you just tell what version of moodle do you use? Is this a version upgraded from 1.9? In 1.9 the completion for teachers was forbidden by default. In 2.x this permission is not set. If you have an upgraded version you should go to "Site administration/Users/Permissions/Define roles". Go to the role editingteacher and than edit this. Switch to the advanced view. Search the permission "mod/feedback:complete" and select "Not set". Now you should be able to override this role inside your feedback-instance in your course. I hope it helps Best regards
Comment 4: Thank you for your response, I should have pointed that I'm using version 2.2.5+. I tried to do as you described, but there seem to be a problem with this. This capability was already set to "Not set" for the role editingteacher (which I have a different name for in my installation). I tried to set it to enabled, and this made teachers able to answer feedbacks site-wide. What I would like is that I have to option to give them this role on select feedbacks. Could this be a "feature" of 2.2?
Comment 5: Hi Fadi, as I mentioned before you have to override the permission in the feedback-instance its self. 1) Go into your course 2) Click on your feedback you want to use for your teachers 3) Click on "Permissions" inside the block "Settings" 4) In the dropdown list "Advanced role override" choose "Teacher" or how ever your teacher role is named 5) Look for "mod/feedback:complete" and set it to "Allow" 6) Click on "Save changes" Your teachers should be able to complete this feedback now. Best regards Andreas
Comment 6: Thank you Andreas, I tried to do that, but in the droplist in the "Advanced role override" I only have "teacher" (non-editing), "student" and "guest". If you were successful in doing that, what version are you using? Best regards, Fadi
Comment 7: Hi Fadi, you have to do this as a user with the permission to override the teacher role. If you don't have this permission you should ask your administrator to give you that or do the setting for you. Best regards Andreas
Comment 8: Good point, I was trying to do this from a regular editing-teacher account. Although I'm the admin for the site, but I wanted to make sure the possibility was there for normal users. I tried this now with my admin account, and yes, the drop-list had all the site roles. Now the question becomes: How to do this in a safe way. To give this capability to normal teachers, I'll have to give the teacher role, the ability to override it. Which is off by default, and I don't know what the reprecussions would be. Is this really such an extreme use-case?! I think I should put more thought into this!
Comment 9: Hi, another possible way is to assign the teachers as student locally to your feedback. 1) go into your feedback 2) go to "Locally assigned roles" 3) assign your teachers as student The teachers should be able to complete the feedback too. Best regards Andreas
Comment 10: Thank you very much Andreas, this did the trick! But looking around I found an issue, related to a several issues in the tracker that you seem to have been involved with, MDL-29770 , MDL-29443 , MDL-14524 and MDL-14781 After giving other teachers (including me) the student role, their names were included in the non-respondents page, which is good. But although the resourse was restricted to a grouping that includes only these teachers, the non-respondents page listed all students of the course. It seems that this page is not respecting this restriction to the grouping. Do you suggest openning a new issue, or is there another similar issue that I'm not aware of? Thanks again, Fadi
Comment 11: Hi Fadi, the grouping functionality is used to control the access to a module. What do you want is the group feature. To use this you have to activate the "Group mode" setting inside your feedback instance. 1) Go into your feedback 2) Go to "Edit settings" 3) Select "Separate groups" or "Visible groups" on the "Group mode" setting. After that you can see a new dropdown list in which you can choose the group you want to filter. Best regards Andreas
Comment 12: This resource was alread in the "Separate groups" mode. And actually, in the "non-respondents" page, near the drop-list, it's mentioned that I'm in a separate groups mode. But to prevent this resource from appearing to students, I have limited it to a grouping that only contains the teachers of this course. So, beside this "Separate groups" notice, I have the name of the grouping inside paranthesis. Now in the drop list, I have two options, "All participants" and the grouping of the teachers. Of course if I choose my grouping it will show just those. But shouldn't "All participants" be limited to the grouping that the resource is limited to? Or is showing all course students considered normal behaviour? Thank you for responding, and I hope I'm not taking much of your time. Take care, Fadi
Comment 13: Hi, as a teacher you can't excluding yourself. That's why you can see "All participants" too. Best regards Andreas
Comment 14: Thanks Andreas,

Post title: Feedback module-responses for individual students not showing
Post description: Although I've set a feedback module to log users' names and show responses' I can't see the individual responses of a student. it reports 'nothing to display'! I can only see the overall class analysis!! We're using version 2 for 2500 users
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lucien, where is the feedback located, in a course or at the frontpage? What moodle version do you use? Did you try this with activated debugging? Andreas
Comment 2: Hi Andreas Thanks for your response. The feedback is in a Moodle course and we're using the latest version of Moodle (2.1) I'm not sure about 'activated debugging'! How do I do this? Is this something for a site administrator or can a lecturer do this? Or is this part of the design of the feedback? Regards Lucien
Comment 3: Hi Lucien, If you do not have admin rights on your moodle installation you have to ask your admin. I need the correct version of your moodle including the build-nr. The debug mode can be turned on in the Menü "Site administration" -> "Development" -> "Debugging". Best regards Andreas
Comment 4: Thanks for this Andreas Below are the current sttings. Which of the following do we turn on? Will this then show the responses to my feedback? Cheers Lucien Debugging Debug messages debug NONE: Do not show any errors or warningsMINIMAL: Show only fatal errorsNORMAL: Show errors, warnings and noticesALL: Show all reasonable PHP debug messagesDEVELOPER: extra Moodle debug messages for developers Default: NONE: Do not show any errors or warnings If you turn this on, then PHP's error_reporting will be increased so that more warnings are printed. This is only useful for developers. Display debug messages debugdisplay Default: No Set to on, the error reporting will go to the HTML page. This is practical, but breaks XHTML , JS, cookies and HTTP headers in general. Set to off, it will send the output to your server logs, allowing better debugging. The PHP setting error_log controls which log this goes to. XML strict headers xmlstrictheaders Default: No Set to on, each page will be generated using XML http headers and prolog, so browsers will show XHTML errors inline. This is only useful for developers. Debug email sending debugsmtp Default: No Enable verbose debug information during sending of email messages to SMTP server. Performance info perfdebug Default: No If you turn this on, performance info will be printed in the footer of the standard theme Show origin of languages strings debugstringids Default: No This option is designed to help translators. It shows the language file and string id beside each string that is output. (Changing this setting will only take effect on the next page load.) Show validator links debugvalidators Default: No Enable if you want to have links to external validator servers in page footer. You may need to create new user with username w3cvalidator , and enable guest access. These changes may allow unauthorized access to server, do not enable on production sites! Show page information debugpageinfo Default: No Enable if you want page information printed in page footer.
Comment 5: Hi Lucien, this are not your current settings but only the labels of your settings. Turn "Debug message" to "All" and "Display debug messages" to "Yes". This will not show your responses. This prints more informations about things what goes wrong. If you have set this setting and saved too then you have to try to show the wanted responses. If there are shown some errors, let me know about it. Please also check: Did you switch the feedback-setting "Record user names" from "Anonymous" to "User's name will be logged" after your students did submit answers? Try an excel-export and have a look at the second worksheet. Are there responses? Best regards Andreas

Post title: Converting feedback answers into useful information for all users...
Post description: Hi all, I'm using the feedback module in order to let users report actions they have done offline. By doing it we pretend to achieve two purposes: - in the admin side, obtain a global statistic of what is being done. By exporting to Excel the submitted data we can do it. - in the user side, we would like to allow all the users to see the answers submitted by others, in order to inspire them for future actions. We have granted all users the "non-editing teacher" role so they can access the answers list and browse every single answer. The results are not bad but we would like to improve the user experience. Does anybody know of a plugin that could convert the feedback answers into a public list of resources (pages) for instance? Any ideas on how doing this? Any help would be appreciated. Thanks in advance! Jaume
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: For those interested on this subject, we finally decided to replace the feedback activity by a database one. We lose some features (required fields, simple analysis upon submitted answers and a few more) but we earn editing capabilities and flexibility on layouts (templates), as well as for inputs as for outputs. And also there is no need to deal with roles and permissions, because by default everybody has the right to see others entries. Jaume

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
Post description: Hi, The feedback activity email notification I am receiving does not link to the specific response that triggered the email... How do I know which answer was submitted? I'm sure I'm doing something wrong. Can anyone help me with this? Thank you in advance, susana
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Susana, unfortunately the feedback notification mail only is linked to the feedback-instance but not to the single response. If your feedback is not anonymous so you can look at the sender address. That's the user who submited the feedback. Best regards Andreas
Comment 2: Use "export to excel", In that exported excel file you can find two sheets "testfeedback" and "detailed". In "detailed" sheet you can find full details of feedback. Try it once Regards, Brahmaiah Petluri ( Edited by Helen Foster to remove signature according to our moodle.org forums code of conduct - original submission Monday, 23 April 2012, 08:16 AM )
Comment 3: Andreas and Brahamaiah, thank you for your comments!! Brahamaiah, I was not able to find any extra information on excel file... I am using anonymous... A feedback timestamp would be enough Thanks, susana
Comment 4: HI, You have to modify the moodle core code. Go to "mod\feedback\lib.php"....search for function "feedback_send_email_anonym"....and edit line below: $info->url = $CFG-> wwwroot .'/mod/feedback/show_entries_anonym.php?id='.$cm->id; your required url is : /feedback/show_entries_anonym.php?id=60& do_show =& showall =& showcompleted =5 So get the remaining parameters and add them to "$info->url"....then you will get the required url to ur mail. Regards, Brami.
Comment 5: Hi, Ok, thanks. I believe that the '5' from "showcompleted=5" in your example, is the entry id. But which variable gives you that parameter? ("id=60" is id=$cm->id... "showcompleted=5" is showcompleted=????) Thanks, susana

Post description: Hello; I'm installing Feedback now on 1.9.6, and I have some concerns about what will happen when we eventually migrate to 2.x. Post title: Need help using "depend item" and "depend value"
Post description: I would like to have a conditional "Other" textbox display depending upon the value of the drop-down list the user selects.  I thought "depend item" and "depend value" would be the answer, however, I am unable to get this to work in Moodle 2.0. For example, I have a drop-down list labeled "statetype" with the following values: ... Wisconsin Wyoming Yukon Territory Other The form input control after the drop-down list is a short text answer labeled "stateother".  On this control, I have the "depend item" set to "statetype" and the "depend value" set to "Other".  My intent was that when the user selects "Other" on the "statetype" drop-down list, the "stateother" textbox would be made visible. The result is that the textbox never shows up regardless of whether "Other" on the drop-down list is selected or not. I have also tried putting a pagebreak between the two form controls and this did not seem to make any difference. Has any one else gotten this to work on Moodle 2.0?  Any ideas regarding what I am doing wrong?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Fred, I have attached an xml -template with an example. You can import it in a blank feedback to test it. Currently there is no javascript to make this feature more userfriendly. Best regards Andreas
Comment 2: Thanks Andreas, that really helped me too! chris
Comment 3: Hi Andreas, Thanks for providing a "conditional branching/skip logic" feature in your Feedback module. However, the example you attached (conditionalquestions.xml) does not have a "logical flow". Scenario #1 Q1 Do you work at home? Student: Never Q2 Why do you work never at home? Student: "blah blah blah" Q3 What Os do you use at home? This is not logical . I would expect that if the student answered "Never" to question 1, the Survey would skip question 3. Scenario #2 So I modified question 3 to make it dependent on Q1 "every day": What Os do you use at home? (workathome->every day). Here is the new scenario. Q1 Do you work at home? Student: Every day Q2 What Os do you use at home? etc. it works OK until the end Scenario #2b Q1 Do you work at home? Student: Never it takes the student to the end of the Survey. The problem is that the choices "often, some day, seldom" should also go to the question about "which OK so you use", but they don't. The way to do this is to add new questions, like this: What Os do you use at home? (workathome->often). What Os do you use at home? (workathome->some days). What Os do you use at home? (workathome->seldom). It would be nice if we had a feature to add in the "depend item" "depend value" field not just one value, but a list of comma-separated values. So, in the example at hand, we would not have to multiply the number of questions, but have all "depend values" together in one question. Joseph
Comment 4: Hi Joseph, thank you, that sounds like a good idea to me! Andreas

Post title: [1.9.9] Feedback for students and Feedback for teachers
Post description: Hi there, How can I do something like this? Two different feedback activities viewable each by students and by teachers? I would also like to post a block on the main page or even a sticky block, but having the same conditions. Thanks in advance
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, in general the roles "student" and "teacher" only are affected in a course. So the feedbacks you need have to be located in the course where the students and teachers are assigned. If you want one feedback for students and one for the teachers so you could separate them with groupings. you can create two groups in your course and then two groupings. Then you create two feedbacks and restrict the access by groupings. The effect is that students and teachers only see the right feedback. Andreas

Post title: Moodle 2.0 Feedback Form Depends Question
Post description: I am brand new to Moodle, working in a sandbox for Moodle 2.0. I have created a Feedback form for course evaluation. At one point is the question: (8)Did you have more than one instructor for this course? a "Yes" answer takes the user past a page break to a list of questions about the second instructor, the first of which depends on (8) having a value of "Yes"  and ends with "Submit" My problem is that if they answer "No" I want them to the see the "Submit" button but can't seem to get it. I am strictly a user, not a programmer. I think I'm just mixing up a step. Can you help please? Susan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Susan, I do not fully understand your problem. Can you describe it more detailed. Andreas
Comment 2: Hi Andreas, Thank you. I will try. Actually, I did solve some of the problem. Here is what the problem is now: I have a feedback activity being used for course evaluations. After some questions, I have one (question #8) which asks: Did you have a second teacher? the choices for an answer are "Yes" or "No". If "Yes" is chosen, the user is taken to another series of questions that depend on question #8 having been answered "Yes". When the user finishes answering those questions, they are able to click "Submit" and all is fine. If the user answered "No" to question #8, they are taken to an information questions that states they are finished and they can click "Submit". The problem is here: when they click "Submit" the form says they have not answered all required questions. Do you know what is causing this? I hope I have given you enough information. Thank you, Susan
Comment 3: Hi Susen, maybe the questions depending on the Yes-answer are mandatory. Andreas
Comment 4: Hi Andreas, I'll bet you are correct. I'll try making them not mandatory. Thanks! Susan
Comment 5: Thanks Andreas, That was the problem and now it works great! Susan

Post title: Can I hide the preview button in Feedback?
Post description: We're finding that students spot the 'preview' icon, click it, think that they're filling out the Feedback form and then wonder why their feedback hasn't been submitted.  The 'answer the questions' link they should be clicking is so small that they're missing it. Therefore I'd like, ideally, to hide the preview icon or, failing that, increase the size of the 'answer the questions' link.  Does anyone know how to do this? Jennie
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Which versions of Moodle and feedback are you using?
Comment 2: Oops, sorry - I'm new to Moodle and to these forums! I'm using Moodle 2.0.3.  I'm not sure what version of Feedback I'm using - it was standard with the installation of Moodle 2.0.3.  If there's a way of finding out which version it is, let me know how to find it and I'll look! Thanks for your help Jennie
Comment 3: Hi Jennie, In cPanel go to /home/pibceduc/public_html/mod/feedback and open view.php. Search for the string below and delete the highlighted part. Nobody will see the preview icon after this. echo $OUTPUT->heading(format_text($feedback->name.' ' .$previewlnk )); With kind regards, Hartmut
Comment 4: Thanks Hartmut, I'll give that a go! Regards Jennie

Comment 6: You can make from a feedback a 360 degree survey, but you needs some more modules for the invitation part and reporting portions. Forum Post: Post title: Feedback - hide null answers in text fields/areas Post description: This is a minor change that one of my curriculum developers requested. We are using moodle 1.9 When viewing the analysis of feedback containing text based answers she wanted to not show the responces where the user did not provide an answer. I accomplished this by adding an if statement to the textfield lib.php and the text area lib.php files.  The respective files can be found in the feedback folder under ../mod/feedback/item/textarea/lib.php and ../mod/feedback/item/textfield/lib.php Under the function print_analysed section look for the foreach statement foreach($values as $value) { echo '-  ' . str_replace("\n", '
', $value->value) . ''; } I added an if statement directly above the echo to echo only if the value was not null. Code is below.... foreach($values as $value) { if($value->value != ""){ echo '-  ' . str_replace("\n", '
', $value->value) . ''; } } I did the same to both the text field and text area questions... works like a charm. Jason Comments associated with the post: No comments posted on the postLabel:

Is there a better way?? Thanks.
Comment 4: Hi Catherine, in the feedback-module for moodle 2.0 you can see users who has not responsed and send them a message but only if the feedback is not anonymous. In moodle 1.9 this feature is not implemented. Andreas
Comment 5: Hi.  It has to be anonymous... So that means there is no alternative to the way I'm doing it? Thanks again.
Comment 6: Catherine - That is correct, if it is anonymous then you do not know who submitted and who did not. One of the critiques when anonymous was first introduced was that by logging it might be possible to determine who submitted which entries. I tried to randomize that but then folks said that you could just put a single user in a group and then sort by groups and see a particular users response and thus defeat anonymity. So then there is no logging of anonymous which means you do not know whether a particular user has completed an entry or not. As a teacher, I can understand wanting to ensure that every student has completed a feedback activity; however, if you compare it to the paper version of a survey there is no way to ensure that every student has in fact completed it. They can always turn one in blank and you would not know who that was. I would have to go back in and check to see if on an anonymous survey the viewing of the feedback is logged (as opposed to actually submitting one). Peace - Anthony
Comment 7: If you have a database developer or moodle programmer it is possible. Although it is anonymous, you can still get the user id from the moodle database. There is a table called mdl_feedback which is a list of all your feedbacks There is another table called mdl_user - all the users on your moodle installation Another table called mdl_feedback_completed - which relates mdl_feedback to mdl_user Using this third table, you can get a list of people who have not completed the feedback and compare it to a list of people on your course. (there are other tables like mdl_course you can use if you want to include filters for people on specific courses) Then either manually email them or again write a quick script to get moodle to email them all. This is usually a job for the E-Learning Developer if you have one. www.osiname.co.uk

Post title: Suggestions / wanted features for feedback
Post description: Feedback is great module. I like and use it much. I have some suggestions / wanted features. I checked the forum and I have not found such a topic. I know Andreas is busy enough anyhow here they are: 1. Please add question type "grid" or "scale". I mean something like docs.google.com has for forms. In one question there are more rows and columns. In rows are options and in columns are weights. Weights may be open or 1,2,3.. or the Likert scale options: Strongly disagree, Disagree, Neither agree nor disagree, Agree, Strongly agree ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Likert_scale ) or Moodle Survey options: Almost never, Seldom, Sometimes, Often, Almost always. Answers are/should be stored in separate fields with names of rows (at least this is how it works in G. docs) 2. In setting-up the feedback (Edit Setting) add option (maybe in the Feedback options section) to Hide the "Not selected" No/Yes as a default option for the whole feedback (which will be default setting for the new feedback or will overwrite already set question (with warning)). In other words: additionally to the option provided for each question set the same for the whole feedback already at setting it up. 3. If the question is edited (not a newly created.. I guess you may check if the question is not the last one or question editor was reached by click on edit button) then please add in Edit Question on the bottom the new button "Save and edit next question" (next to buttons "Save changes to question" "Save as a new question" "Cancel") (and move to edit next question). 4. Pre-fill the labels field with something like SingleA1, MC2, TextS3, TextL4, Drop5 or similar for single answer, multiple choice, short, long text, drop down list etc. I mean something like: type of question+ number. The reason is that in Excel it would be meaningful to know the type of question (at least for me) without checking answers. It does not matter that user may change labels. I am guessing that most users let them empty anyway. 5. Small thing: in my installation (Moodle 2) in Templates/Use a template the text: "No templates available yet" is rendered in two lines. Just one would be enough. This is just a case when there are no templates. I just looked into the source and found that it is because of size of div.fstaticlabel. Maybe I was not clear enough. Do not hesitate to add comments, suggestions.. Thanks Miro

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback module meet FERPA regulations?
Post description: Dear all, just curious, does anyone know if the "feedback" module meets the FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) regulations, and have passed some accessibility tests?? Thanks! Wen
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That is an interesting question, but the Feedback module is, essentially, a survey tool so I am not sure that FERPA regs would even cover it. The Feedback module allows you to create your own surveys, and that would be well and truly policed by any schools, anyone else, well that would be an organizational thing so I doubt FERPA would even apply. As a general rule, one of the core policies of Moodle.org has been to preserve privacy wherever appropriate. The definition of "appropriate" applied by Moodle.org, in my view, has more than a touch of hysterical paranoia about it that is unnecessary. In so many areas Students should not even have an expectation of privacy from Teachers or the School, in general. Obviously this is limited by common sense and good taste, elements of our society that have been sadly lacking in recent decades. Unfortunately, the times we live in dictate that teachers are obviously suspect for wanting to work with children and therefore need to be limited by law to the point where they can no longer perform the duties expected of them. Obviously then, when it goes wrong, as it is, Teachers are being blamed for all of society's problems.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback Analysis:  Percentage for each answer for each question; mean and mode
Post description: Hi. I'm using feedback for student evaluations of courses and instructors. It works fine, but we want to know what percentage of responders chose each answer for each question. Moodle can give us the raw numbers (i.e. 45 people chose answer A on question 3), but we're looking for percentage and also mean, mode, and standard deviation. Right now, we're exporting to Excel and using a macro to calculate this, but has anyone written an add on for this to be done within Moodle's analysis of feedback responses? Thanks in advance for the help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Catherine: Right now, we're exporting to Excel and using a macro to calculate this,... This is the right thing to do. By using your own spreadsheet (or stats package) you are sure to process the data output by feedback exactly the way you want. Not only can you do all the calculations you need but you can output the results to any pie-chart you need. Making the equivalent processing available in the Feedback module itself would take a lot of programing time and ... then end-user would probably never be satisfied. Joseph

Post title: Responses
Post description: Hi I want to be able to show in a block a previous answer for a student which they have submitted to a feedback. For example, you rated the course as 7 on your previous visit, please indicate your new rating. Where can the previous answers be found in the database ? Stu
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, if the feedback is nonanonymous so only a single set of answers is saved. Therefore no previous answers exists if the student save new answers. If the feedback is anonymous so you do not find out what is the previous answer due to its anonymity. You can find the answers in the table "feedback_value". These values are related to a record in "feedback_completed" and "feedback_item". Andreas

Forum Post: 
Post title: Module blocks: /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/blocks/version.php was not readable
Post description: I installed Feedback and right after the installation I received the following error: Module blocks: /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/blocks/version.php was not readable Then after I refreshed and I am know receiving the following two errors: Module "blocks" is not readable - check permissions Module "mod" is not readable - check permissions Strangely enough, the feedback activity works fine, but the errors at the top of the main page are annoying. Any ideas on how to stop them?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is no module called "blocks" or "mod" so you have probably unzipped content of feedback zip package directly to yoursite/mod subfolder and not the site main folder. Delete folders /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/blocks and /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/mod and reinstall (unzip) files of feedback so that you have folders /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/feedback and /home/eprofess/public_html/school/blocks/feedback Login back to your site and click Notifications (first link in administration menu) or visit http://www.yoursite.xxx/admin/index.php and you should not get those messages anymore.
Comment 2: Thank you so much!

Post title: Installed Feedback, but getting no option to create feedback
Post description: I am running Moodle 1.9.6 and have recently installed the Feedback module for Moodle 1.9.x. I followed all of the directions for this, with putting the /mod/feedback under /mod and /blocks/feedback under /blocks. I went into Notifications, and that was set up properly. This is all I am seeing: Allow full anonymous NoYes Default: No If this option is set yes so the feedback can be completed whithout any preceding logon. It only affects feedbacks on the mainpage. Any thoughts on what might be going on and how I can get this working? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, I'm in the same situation as you, did you find a solution? Thank you.
Comment 2: Hi, somtimes feedbacks should be completed without any login but also without guest login. This is possible if you set the module-setting "Allow full anonymous" to "yes". Only feedbacks on the frontpage of your moodle-installation are affected and only if these are set to anonymous and multiple submit. To create a feedback you have to do this like adding other activities. If you want to use the feedback-block please have a look at this post . I'm hoping it helps a bit. Andreas
Comment 3: mmmm I must admit that this got me too. Installed and not a lot happened, Notifications told me it was setup properly and so on, but did not get the tabs to allow me to create feedback. Nothing. Tried lots of different things and still nothing, then had a brainwave, it hates me. So I closed Moodle and restarted it - after all, I am in charge here, not the program. And it worked. Here am I, spoilt by things just working when installed, hot installs, I get an odd one, not a hot install and have a hissy because of it. Unbelievable, damn computers....
Comment 4: I will admit I am new to Moodle, so I will give a screenshot of what I am seeing. http://screencast.com/t/OTI3YzI0YjIt I don't see how to add new Feedback http://screencast.com/t/Y2JkNGFkYT I also tried adding it as a Sticky Block, but no luck there... Any help is appreciated Thanks
Comment 5: Hi, the feedback activity only can be created in the same way like other modules e.g. forum, quiz and so on. If you want to use the feedback block so you have to create a feedback on the frontpage of your moodle-installation. After creation you can map some courses to that global feedback. All mapped courses now can use the feedback-block. In this block only mapped feedbacks are shown. If you don't use feedbacks on the frontpage you never need the feedback-block. You only need the feedback-activity. Andreas

Post title: dropdown(rated) fields in straight html so we can populate them
Post description: When I am creating a lot of quizes I put default values that I need for the quiz intro in to the file moodle/mod/quiz/mod.html If there were a similar file for dropdown rated, then I could edit that file and not have to copy and paste 1 strongly disagreel 2 disagree 3 mildly disagree 4 neither disagree nor agree 5 mildly agree 6 agree 7 agree completely Every time I created one of many Dropdown (rated) questions. I guess that there is a way of using a template but the template seems to be for the whole quiz, rather than for questions, and I have a variety of ratings in a single test. If I were better at php I would be able to change the php, probably this line $item->presentation=empty($item->presentation)?'':$item->presentation; Which I think is saying if item->presentation is empty then make it equal to an empty string or leave it equal to itself???? to $item->presentation=empty($item->presentation)?'strongly disagree|disagree|midly disagree|neither disagree nor agree|mildly agree|agree|agree completely':$item->presentation; But that did not work. nor did $item->presentation=empty($item->presentation)?'1|strongly disagree|2|disagree|3|midly disagree|4|neither disagree nor agree|5|mildly agree|6|agree|7|agree completely':$item->presentation; nor did $item->presentation=empty($item->presentation)?'1,strongly disagree|2,disagree|3,midly disagree|4,neither disagree nor agree|5,mildly agree|6,agree|7,agree completely':$item->presentation; Tim
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ah, the value seperator was at the top of the page. I did an echo itemp->presentation and then edited a created drop down menu to find this (the seperators can be defined at the top of the drowndownrated/lip.php file. 1####Yes|2####Probably|3####Probably Not|4####No So The following change $item->presentation=empty($item->presentation)?'':$item->presentation; to $item->presentation=empty($item->presentation)?'1####strongly disagree|2####disagree|3####midly disagree|4####neither disagree nor agree|5####mildly agree|6####agree|7####agree completely':$item->presentation; Seems to work. remember to save lib.php using UTF-8 ecoding if using a non ascii language. Hack with great care, on non production systems after backing up. Tim

Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback install problems
Post description: I'm running moodle 1.9 on a Windows 2003/XP server , MySQL 5.0.51, PHP 5.2.5 I want to install the feedback module. I'm relatively new to being a moodle admin, but I have managed to successfully install moodle and I have several courses going for our school district. This is the first time I have attempted to install a module.  The module installation instructions at moodle.org say to " Download the zip file and unzip it to your moodle/mod directory." My moodle root seems to be in C:\Inetpub\ wwwroot . I unzipped and dropped the feedback_19 folder in there. I then logged in as admin and checked my modules and received this message: Module feedback_19: C:\Inetpub\wwwroot/mod/feedback_19/version.php was not readable. Can someone give me a hint as to what the problem might be and how I can solve it? Thanks for your help!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: OK, it's me again. I'm still confused but on further investigation I found: In the unzipped feedback_19 folder there are two folders: "blocks" and "mod". In the blocks folder there is a "feedback" folder and in that a "lang" folder and a "block_feedback.php" file. In the "mod" folder there is also a "feedback" folder and in that several folders and files and most of the files are php files. So, it seems like dropping the whold feedback_19 folder is not the thing to do, but installing some of the folders that are contained in that folder might work, but there is not readme file that explains. Can anyone explain which folders to put in my moodle\mods folder to make it work? Thanks so much! Ken Russell Bellingham Schools
Comment 2: Ken, Feedback is a module, but there is also a feedback block that can be used to access global feedbacks from courses. So, copy the stuff in feedback_19/mod into your moodle/mod folder, and the stuff in feedback_19/blocks goes into your moodle/blocks folder. -Ann
Comment 3: Ann, Thank you for your help. Is there someone to contact and suggest that some simple instructions about this could be added in a readme file along with the download, and/or also added to the download page for this module? That way you would not have people like me asking questions. I love moodle but often find that the documentation is sketchy. Forum Post: 
Post title: Feedback - Mapping Feedback to courses
Post description: We are attempting to use the Feedback Module to facilitate our course evaluations. I have two questions 1. Is there a method to map feedback to a specfic course? 2. Is there a method to provide conditional access or manually provide access for a student to complete a course evaluation without opening the evaluation for all members of course.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, 1) I'm not sure what do you mean. If you use the feedback-block with feedbacks on the frontpage so you can map single courses to this feedback. 2) conditional access will be supported first on moodle 2. Currently you can define a grouping to limit the access to specific students. Andreas
Comment 2: From what I read - there are two ways to use this feature: Globally or per course. Per course uses the mod as an activity but you can only access the reports per courses - which is time consuming for an administrator. We are using 1.8 on MySQL and the block wouldnt work, but we wanted it to appear as an activity in the syllabus rather than a block within the course as the students might consider it very optional rather than part of the course. So here's the step by step of what we did: 1) Install feedback module and create an instance of the Feedback Survey on the HOME page of Moodle.  Create the questions and save. 2) To map the courses - type in something to filter your course selections with.  All our course shortcodes include the term month (_Apr).  This builds a list to select from. 3) Once the survey is complete and the courses have been added - you can add the survey link to the actual courses.    I used the following:   Add resource, Add link to file or website.  The URL used was the direct link to the survey in the HOME course with an added parameter of courseid = Course.id   This ensures that the data is associated with the course. Any course that has this link that is not mapped yet - should display an error.
Comment 3: revised post - the block did work - I was doing things in the wrong order ... thanks Andreas!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Aggregation of Feedback results across whole Moodle site
Post description: I work for a FE College in the UK. Our moodle has around 700 courses on it, and depending on the students on the course, they are asked to complete one of four surveys using Feedback. The problem is that while the results of the feedback are visible within the scope of the course, the survey is a cross-college survey and as such we need the Feedback to be in the scope of the whole Moodle, if that makes sense. (Basically, we need details of every survey collated together on one page.) I have seen that a Feedback can be palced onto the front page of Moodle, but then it does not collect the course the student is taking, or the Teacher of the course, which we also need. Our current solution is to hack out some PHP which queries the feedback tables in the database directly, looking for instances of "Student Survey 1 - Feb 2009" or similar, and gathers results, producing a custom-build page of textual results. This page has no graphs and is not something which could easily be ported to other Moodles (id-specific user authentication and such), as well as repeating all the text in the questions, so if the questions change (which they inevitably will) the code neds changing too. Is there the possibility that Feedback can be extended to include surveys in the global scope? Ideally we need more information to be collected which we do not currently store in Moodle (such as which department the course is in, e.g. Hair and Beauty or Automotive) but that's for a different discuaaion thread. Regards,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: For what it is worth I have added this to the Tracker at MDL-1842 I think the Feedback activity with a cross-Moodle scope would be a formidable tool. Please vote as you see fit.
Comment 2: Hi Paul, please have a look at the feedback-block. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=70873&parent=319017 Andreas
Comment 3: Hi Andreas. Instead of reporting my thoughts here I have added to the tracker. Paul.
